PREFACE
         This code of the Village of Heyworth, as supplemented, contains
ordinances up to and including ordinance 2025-56, passed September 16, 2025,
and resolution 2023- , passed May 18, 2023. Ordinances of the Village adopted
after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this code to the extent that
they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the Village office in
order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the code has been
amended, superseded or repealed.
                     American Legal Publishing
                     Cincinnati, Ohio
ORDINANCES PENDING REVIEW FOR CODIFICATION
Listed ordinances have been passed, but they are pending review by the
publisher, and they may not affect the code of ordinances. Additionally,
ordinances listed in this section may not show the original ordinances in their
entirety. Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions
concerning any listed ordinances.
 
 
TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATION
CHAPTER 1
HEYWORTH VILLAGE CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Code Alterations
1-1-5: Custody And Copies Of Code
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon the adoption by the village board of trustees, this code is hereby
declared to be and shall hereafter constitute the official village code of
Heyworth. This code of ordinances shall be known and cited as the HEYWORTH
VILLAGE CODE and is hereby published by authority of the board of trustees and
shall be supplemented to incorporate the most recent legislation of the village
as provided in section
1-1-3 of this chapter. Any reference to the number of any section contained
herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same number, its
appropriate chapter and title heading, and to the general penalty clause
relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is made to
this code by title in any legal documents. (2011 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received
without further proof in all courts and in administrative tribunals of this
state as the ordinances of the village of general and permanent effect, except
the excluded ordinances enumerated in section
1-2-1 of this title. (2011 Code)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending this code shall set forth the title, chapter and section
number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall constitute
sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to the
amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this code. All such
amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to the
codifiers, and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in
its proper place in each copy of this code. Each such replacement page shall be
properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of this code.
(2011 Code)
1-1-4: CODE ALTERATIONS:
It shall be deemed unlawful for any person to alter, change, replace or deface
in any way any section or any page of this code in such a manner that the
meaning of any phrase or order may be changed or omitted. Said code, while in
actual possession of officials and other interested persons, shall be and
remain the property of the village and shall be returned to the office of the
village clerk when directed so to do by order of the village board of trustees.
(2011 Code)
1-1-5: CUSTODY AND COPIES OF CODE:
   A.   Official Copies: The village clerk shall keep two (2) copies of this
code current. These copies shall be preserved by the village clerk so that all
amendments thereto and all general ordinances hereafter passed may be inserted
in their appropriate places in such volumes, and all sections of this code or
ordinances repealed from time to time may be extracted therefrom for the
purpose of maintaining such two (2) copies in such condition that they will
show all general ordinances passed up to date at any time in such manner that
ready reference may be had thereto. (1981 Code § 1-7; amd. 2011 Code)
   B.   Custody And Distribution Of Copies: All the printed codes containing
the revised ordinances shall be in the custody and keeping of the village
clerk. The mayor shall have authority to extend to or reciprocate courtesies of
other cities by presenting to them a copy of this code bound at the expense of
the village in such a manner as to him may seem advisable. (1981 Code § 1-15)
   C.   Purchase Price: Printed copies of this code and any ordinance imposing
any fine, penalty, imprisonment, or forfeiture, or making any appropriation
which may be printed in book or pamphlet form, published by authority of the
village board, shall, so long as such books or pamphlets are in supply, be
available for distribution to the public. The board may impose a reasonable
price commensurate with the cost of the printing thereof for the distribution
of such book or pamphlet to the public. (1981 Code § 1-16)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal Of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Public Ways And Public Utility Ordinances
1-2-3: Court Proceedings
1-2-4: Severability Clause
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
   A.   Ordinances Repealed And Ordinances Saved From Repeal: All general
ordinances of the village passed prior to the adoption of this code are hereby
repealed, except such as are included in this code or are by necessary
implication herein reserved from repeal (subject to the saving clauses
contained in the following sections), and excluding the following ordinances
which are not hereby repealed: ordinances relating to boundaries and
annexations; franchise ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights
to persons or corporations; contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the
execution of a contract or the issuance of warrants; salary ordinances;
ordinances establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other public
places; improvement ordinances; bond ordinances; ordinances relating to
elections; ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate by
or from the village; and all special ordinances.
   B.   Limitations On Repeal: The repeal of the ordinances, as provided in
subsection A of this section, shall not affect any debt or fee which is
accrued, any duty imposed, any penalty incurred, nor any action or proceeding
commenced under or by virtue of the ordinances repealed or the term of office
of any person holding office at the time these ordinances take effect; nor
shall the repeal of any ordinance have the effect of reviving any ordinance
heretofore repealed or superseded. (2011 Code)
1-2-2: PUBLIC WAYS AND PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroad crossings with streets and other public ways,
or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public utilities shall
be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this code or by virtue of section
1-2-1 of this chapter, excepting as this code may contain provisions for such
matters, in which case, this code shall be considered as amending such
ordinance or ordinances with respect to such provisions only. (2011 Code)
1-2-3: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
   A.   Prior Acts: No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a
former ordinance, whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not,
as to any offense committed against such former ordinance or as to any act
done, any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued
or claim arising under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect
any such offense or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or
punishment so incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new
ordinance takes effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform
to the ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as
practicable. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment may be mitigated by any
provision of a new ordinance, such provision may be, by consent of the party
affected, applied to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes
effect.
   B.   Extend To All Repeals: This section shall extend to all repeals, either
by express words or implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making
any new provisions upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
   C.   Current Pending Actions: Nothing contained in this chapter shall be
construed as abating any action now pending under or by virtue of any general
ordinance of the village herein repealed, and the provisions of all general
ordinances contained in this code shall be deemed to be continuing provisions
and not a new enactment of the same provisions; nor shall this chapter be
deemed as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or
to accrue, or as affecting the liability of any person, firm or corporation, or
as waiving any right of the village under any ordinance or provision thereof in
force at the time of the adoption of this code. (2011 Code)
1-2-4: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
If any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this code,
or any codes or portions of codes adopted herein by reference, is for any
reason held to be unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by any court of
competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or
effectiveness of the remaining portions of this code, or any codes or portions
of codes adopted herein by reference. The village board of trustees hereby
declares that it would have passed each section, subsection, paragraph,
sentence, clause or phrase thereof irrespective of the fact that any one or
more sections, subsections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses or phrases be
declared unconstitutional, invalid or ineffective. (2011 Code)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS; INTERPRETATION
SECTION:
1-3-1: General Rules Of Interpretation
1-3-2: General Definitions
1-3-3: Catchlines
1-3-1: GENERAL RULES OF INTERPRETATION:
   A.   Liberal Construction: All general provisions, terms, phrases and
expressions contained in this code shall be liberally construed in order that
the true intent and meaning of the mayor and board of trustees may be fully
carried out.
   B.   Minimum Requirements: In the interpretation and application of any
provision of this code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted
for the promotion of the public health, safety and general welfare.
   C.   Computation Of Time: Whenever a notice is required to be given or an
act to be done in a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had,
the day on which such notice is given or such act is done shall not be counted
in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be held shall
be counted.
   D.   Official Time: Official time shall be that designated by the law of the
state of Illinois.
   E.   Delegation Of Authority: Whenever a provision appears requiring the
head of a department or some other village officer to do some act or perform
some duty, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department or
other officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the
required act or perform the duty unless the terms of the provision or section
specify otherwise.
   F.   Gender: A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be
applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to
males.
   G.   Joint Authority: All words giving a joint authority to three (3) or
more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a
majority of such persons or officers.
   H.   May; Shall: The word "may" is permissive; the word "shall" is
mandatory.
   I.   Or; And: "Or" may be read "and", and "and" may be read "or", if the
sense requires it.
   J.   Nontechnical And Technical Words: Words and phrases shall be construed
according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words
and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate
meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning.
   K.   Number: A word importing the singular number only may extend and be
applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing.
   L.   Officers And Employees Generally: Whenever any officer or employee is
referred to by title only, such reference shall be construed as if followed by
the words "of the village of Heyworth".
   M.   Tense: Words used in the past or present tense include the future as
well as the past and present.
   N.   Ordinance: The word "ordinance" contained in the ordinances of the
village has been changed in the content of this code to "title", "chapter",
"section" and/or "subsection" or words of like import for organizational and
clarification purposes only. Such change to village ordinances is not meant to
amend passage and effective dates of such original ordinances. (1981 Code §§ 1-
2, 1-20; amd. 2011 Code)
   O.   Position Of Authority Not Filled; Delegation: Whenever a provision
appears requiring the head of a department or some other village officer to do
some act or perform some duty and if there is no individual currently appointed
to or filling that position, that provision shall defer to the mayor or mayor's
designee to administer or carry out that provision unless otherwise prohibited
by law.
   P.   Enforcement Official If Not Otherwise Specified or Prohibited: If a
specif-ic section or chapter of the Village code does not specify an
enforcement offi-cial or position responsible for enforcement of that specific
section or chapter, a Village Code Compliance Officer shall be that enforcement
official unless otherwise prohibited by law. (1981 Code §§ 1-2, 1-20; amd. 2011
Code; Ord. 2013-16, 4-25-2013; Ord. 2024-57, 11-7-2024)
1-3-2: GENERAL DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this code, they shall have
the meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meaning
repugnant thereto:
AGENT: A person acting on behalf of another with authority conferred, either
expressly or by implication.
BOARD OR BOARD OF TRUSTEES: Unless otherwise indicated, the village board of
trustees of the village of Heyworth.
CODE: The village code of the village of Heyworth.
COUNTY: The county of McLean, state of Illinois.
IN THE VILLAGE OR WITHIN THE VILLAGE: All territory over which the village now
has or shall hereafter acquire jurisdiction for the exercise of its police
powers or other regulatory powers.
LICENSE: The permission granted for the carrying on of a business, profession
or occupation.
MAYOR: The duly elected president of the board of trustees of the village of
Heyworth.
MUNICIPAL AND FISCAL YEAR: The municipal year and the fiscal year of the
village shall commence on May 1 of each year and end on April 30 of the
following year.
NUISANCE: Anything offensive to the sensibilities of reasonable persons, or any
act or activity creating a hazard which threatens the health and welfare of
inhabitants of the village, or any activity which, by its perpetuation, can
reasonably be said to have a detrimental effect on the property of a person or
persons within the community.
OCCUPANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who
occupies the whole or any part of such building or land, whether alone or with
others.
OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provision of this code or the omission of any
act required by the provisions of this code.
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: As applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint
owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of a part of
such building or land.
PERSON: Any public or private corporation, firm, partnership, association,
organization, government or any other group acting as a unit, as well as a
natural person.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Includes every species of property except "real property" as
defined in this section.
PRECEDING; FOLLOWING: Next before and next after, respectively.
PROPERTY: Shall include real and personal property.
REAL PROPERTY: Shall include lands, tenements, and hereditaments and shall
embrace all chattels real.
RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate
to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things direct to the consumer.
RIGHT OF WAY: The privilege of the immediate use of the roadway or other
property.
SIDEWALK: That portion of a street between the curb lines, or the lateral lines
of a roadway and the adjacent property lines, intended for the use of
pedestrians.
STATE: The state of Illinois.
STREET: The entire width between property lines of every way or place of
whatever nature when any part thereof is open to the use of the public, as a
matter of right, for purposes of vehicular traffic.
TENANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies
the whole or any part of such building or land, whether alone or with others.
VILLAGE: The village of Heyworth, county of McLean, state of Illinois.
WHOLESALER AND WHOLESALE DEALER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall
be understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things
to persons who purchase for the purpose of resale.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING: May include printing and any other mode of representing
words and letters, but when the written signature of any person is required by
law on any official or public writing or bond, it shall be in the proper
handwriting of such person or, in case such person is unable to write, by such
person's proper mark. (1981 Code §§ 1-2, 2-2.10; amd. 2011 Code)
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of this code are intended as mere
catchwords to indicate the content of the section and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of such sections, nor be deemed to govern, limit, modify or
in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any
section hereof, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when
any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (2011
Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty
1-4-2: Application Of Provisions
1-4-3: Liability Of Officers
1-4-4: Suits For Violations
1-4-5: Summons Or Warrant
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY 1 :
   A.   General Penalty Imposed: Unless specifically provided elsewhere in this
Code or State Statute, any person found to have been in violation of any of the
terms and provisions of this Code shall be fined in an amount not less than
fifty dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
No imprisonment for failure to pay such fine, penalty or cost shall exceed six
(6) months for each offense. Each day that a violation continues shall be
deemed to be a separate offense. A penalty for each offense may include a
requirement that the offending party perform some reasonable public service
work such as, but not limited to, picking up litter in public parks or upon
public highways or performing maintenance of public facilities. A violation
hereof may be established by a preponderance of the evidence. (Ord. 2018-30, 6-
21-2018)
   B.   Acts Consistent With Criminal Laws Of State: If, by the terms of an
ordinance, an act that would be consistent with the criminal laws of the State,
is declared to be a misdemeanor, the penalty therefor shall be for a period of
incarceration in a penal institution other than the penitentiary not to exceed
six (6) months. The matter shall be prosecuted under the Rules of Criminal
Procedure of the State, and the Village shall be required to establish guilt
beyond a reasonable doubt.
   C.   Other Remedies: In addition to any other remedy specified herein or in
any section of this Code, the Village may seek any other remedy provided for by
law, which may include, but is not limited to, an order to remedy a violation
of any ordinance or violation, or to prohibit future violations.
   D.   Limitation; Compliance With Statute: The provisions of subsection A of
this section notwithstanding, no penalty shall be greater than that established
by State Statute for the same offense.
   E.   Fines: If a fine is not paid by the date specified by the notice of
violation, each minimum fine specified shall increase in the amount of twenty
five dollars ($25.00). (Ord. 2013-37, 9-19-2013)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1, 5/1-2-1.1.
1-4-2: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   Application Of Penalty: The penalty provided in this chapter shall be
applicable to every section of this Code the same as though it were a part of
each and every separate section.
   B.   Acts Punishable Under Different Sections: In all cases where the same
offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of
this Code, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed, but not
more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same
offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or permit shall not be
considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced.
   C.   Breach Of Provisions: Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to
do any act constitutes a breach of any section or provision of this Code and
there shall be no fine or penalty specifically declared for such breach, the
provisions of this chapter shall apply. (2011 Code)
1-4-3: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this Code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of
the Village Board of Trustees to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or
employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the
duty. (2011 Code)
1-4-4: SUITS FOR VIOLATIONS:
All actions brought to enforce any fine, imprisonment, penalty or forfeiture
under this Code or other ordinances of the Village shall be brought in the
corporate name of the Village as plaintiff. No prosecution, recovery,
conviction, or acquittal for a violation of any provision of this Code or any
other ordinance of the Village shall constitute a defense to any prosecution of
the same party for any other violation of the same provision of this Code or
same ordinance or any other Code provision or ordinance, although the different
causes of action existed at the same time, and if united, would not have
exceeded the jurisdiction of the court. (1981 Code § 1-8)
1-4-5: SUMMONS OR WARRANT:
In all actions for the violation of any provision of this Code or other
ordinance of the Village, the first process shall be a summons or a warrant. A
warrant for the arrest of an accused person may issue upon the affidavit of any
person that a provision of this Code or a Village ordinance has been violated,
and that the person making the complaint has reasonable grounds to believe that
the party charged is guilty thereof. Every person arrested upon a warrant shall
be taken before the court for trial. (1981 Code § 1-9)
ARTICLE A. SETTLEMENT OF ORDINANCE VIOLATIONS
SECTION:
1-4A-1: Procedures For Settlement Of Ordinance Violations
1-4A-2: Settlement Of Certain First Ordinance Violation Charges
1-4A-3: Settlement Of Certain Second Ordinance Violation Charges
1-4A-4: Protest Or Nonsettlement Of Ordinance Violations
1-4A-5: Disposition Of Fines And Penalties
1-4A-1: PROCEDURES FOR SETTLEMENT OF ORDINANCE VIOLATIONS:
   A.   Authority To Issue Ordinance Violations: The Village Police Department
or other designee authorized by the Board of Trustees is hereby authorized to
issue ordinance violations to any person or business entity that hereinafter
violates any ordinance of the Village. (Ord. 2009-70, 5-18-2009)
   B.   Issuance And Notice Of Ordinance Violations: The enforcement official
of a particular ordinance of the Village shall submit notice of the ordinance
violation as specified in that ordinance. If notice procedures are not
specifically set forth in an ordinance, the notice procedures set forth in this
subsection shall apply.
      1.   The enforcement officer and/or relevant prosecuting official(s)
shall issue a citation or other appropriate charging documents for an ordinance
violation to the person or business entity by personal delivery or as
authorized by law.
      2.   The notice, or combination of charging documents, shall specify and
include:
         a.   The ordinance that is violated;
         b.   The person, business, or property that is in violation;
         c.   The date and time at which the violation occurred;
         d.   The minimum penalty that may be imposed for the violation;
         e.   The location at which the payment of fine may be paid;
         f.   The address, if known, of the person, business or property in
violation;
         g.   Name the Village as the prosecuting authority;
         h.   A statement whether the person in violation is required to appear
in court and, if so, the date, time and place of appearance;
         i.   If applicable, the steps the person in violation can take to
avoid an otherwise required appearance; and
         j.   A statement that the defendant may demand a jury trial by filing
a jury demand and paying a jury demand fee when entering his or her appearance,
plea, answer to the charge, or other responsive pleading.
      3.   All persons receiving a notice of violation or combination of
charging documents for an ordinance violation may either:
         a.   Pay the fine amount specified on the notice of violation to the
address provided on the notice; or
         b.   Appear on the date, time, and location specified on the notice or
other charging documents at which a person may protest the ordinance violation.
      4.   If a warrant or default judgment will be sought, the notice or
charging documents shall also include a statement that:
         a.   A default judgement may be entered in the event the person fails
to appear in court or answer the charge made on the date set for the
defendant's court appearance or any date to which the case is continued, as
well as the specific amount of any default judgment; and
         b.   An arrest warrant may issue if the defendant fails to appear at
any hearing. (Ord. 2019-53, 10-3-2019)
1-4A-2: SETTLEMENT OF CERTAIN FIRST ORDINANCE VIOLATION CHARGES:
Persons or business entities who have received a citation for violation of the
sections of this Code hereinafter listed or other applicable sections of this
Code may settle an initial ordinance violation charge by paying the amount set
forth in this section or as specifically set forth in the applicable section of
this Code. (Ord. 2019-53, 10-3-2019)

1-4A-3: SETTLEMENT OF CERTAIN SECOND ORDINANCE VIOLATION CHARGES:
Any persons or business entities with a violation of a Village ordinance who
has previously settled a charge pursuant to section
1-4A-2 of this article or has received court supervision or been convicted of
any Village ordinance violation may settle the second violation by payment as
set forth in section
1-4A-2 of this article, plus an additional one hundred dollars ($100.00) unless
otherwise specified in section
1-4A-2 of this article or in the specific nuisance or ordinance alleged to be
violated. (Ord. 2019-53, 10-3-2019)
1-4A-4: PROTEST OR NONSETTLEMENT OF ORDINANCE VIOLATIONS:
If any person or business entity either protests a citation or other charging
documents issued for an ordinance violation or does not meet the requirements
set forth in this article to settle an ordinance violation, the notice of the
date, time and location of the ordinance violation location shall constitute
notice for purposes hereof. If a citation with the date, time and location of
when and where to protest an ordinance violation is not personally served, a
summons shall be issued, by certified mail return receipt requested, to the
violating party. If a party protests or does not settle an ordinance violation
as set forth in this article, that party may not later settle the ordinance
violation except at the location specified by the Village for the prosecution
of ordinance violations. (Ord. 2019-53, 10-3-2019)
1-4A-5: DISPOSITION OF FINES AND PENALTIES:
All fines, penalties, and forfeitures for the violation of ordinances, when
collected, shall be paid into the Treasury of the Village. (Ord. 2009-70, 5-18-
2009)
CHAPTER 5
OFFICIAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS
SECTION:
1-5-1: Ordinances
1-5-2: Corporate Seal
1-5-3: Electronic Participation Or Remote Attendance Policy For Public Meetings
1-5-1: ORDINANCES:
   A.   Enacting Style: The enacting style of all ordinances shall be: "Be it
ordained by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Heyworth".
(1981 Code § 1-10)
   B.   Signature Required: All ordinances passed by the village must be signed
by the mayor or by two (2) members of the board of trustees. (1981 Code § 1-11)
   C.   Record And Memorandum Required: The village clerk shall record, in a
book used exclusively for that purpose, all ordinances passed by the village.
Immediately following each ordinance, the village clerk shall make a memorandum
of the date of the passage and publication, where required, of the ordinance.
This record and memorandum, or a certified copy thereof, shall be prima facie
evidence of the contents, passage, and publication of ordinances. (1981 Code §
1-12; amd. 2011 Code)
   D.   Proof Of Ordinances:
      1.   The contents of all village ordinances, the date of passage, and the
date of publication, where required, may be proved by the certificate of the
village clerk, under the seal of the village. (1981 Code § 1-13; amd. 2011
Code)
      2.   Whenever village ordinances are printed in book or pamphlet form and
purport to be published by authority of the village, such book or pamphlet
shall be prima facie evidence of the contents, passage, and legal publication
of such ordinances, as of the dates mentioned in such book or pamphlet, in all
courts and administrative tribunals. (1981 Code § 1-13)
   E.   Publication; Effective Dates: All ordinances of the village imposing
any fine, penalty, imprisonment or forfeiture, or making any appropriation,
shall comply with 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2-4, as amended. (1981 Code
§ 1-14; amd. 2011 Code)
1-5-2: CORPORATE SEAL:
   A.   Description: A seal or disk in a circular form with the words "Village
of Heyworth, Illinois" on the outer circle, and in the interior and center of
said circle the word "seal", shall be the seal of the village, to be used in
all cases that have been or shall hereafter be provided by the laws of the
United States, the laws of the several respective states of the United States,
and the ordinances of the village, and in all cases in which, by laws and
customs of corporations, it is necessary to use a seal by a corporation. (1981
Code § 1-18)
   B.   Custodian; Official Use: The village clerk shall be the custodian of
the corporate seal. He shall affix the impression of the corporate seal to all
commissions or other official documents required to be issued by him and attest
or countersign the same. He shall affix the seal to all official acts of the
mayor which require it and, if necessary, attest the same. He shall also
certify, under the corporate seal, copies of any records, ordinances,
documents, or papers in his office when required by any village officer or
other person. In no case shall the impression of the corporate seal be binding
upon the village, unless it be authorized by the laws or ordinances of the
village and is attested by the official signature of the village clerk. (1981
Code § 1-19)
1-5-3: ELECTRONIC PARTICIPATION OR REMOTE ATTENDANCE POLICY FOR PUBLIC
MEETINGS:
   A.   Policy Statement: It is the policy of the village that any member of
the village may attend and participate in any open or closed meeting of the
village from a remote location by way of telephone, video or internet
connection; provided, that such attendance and participation is in compliance
with this policy and any other applicable laws.
   B.   Definition Of Meetings: The term "meeting", as used in this section,
refers to any gathering, whether in person or by video or audio conference,
telephone call, electronic means (such as, without limitation, electronic mail,
electronic chat, and instant messaging), or other means of contemporaneous
interactive communication, of a majority of a quorum of the members of a public
body held for the purposes of discussing public business.
   C.   Prerequisites: A member of the village may attend a meeting from a
remote location if the member meets the following conditions:
      1.   A quorum is physically present throughout the meeting; and
      2.   A majority of a quorum of the village votes to approve the remote
attendance; and
      3.   The member should notify the village clerk at least twenty four (24)
hours before the meeting so that necessary communications equipment can be
arranged. Inability to make the necessary technical arrangements will result in
denial of a request for remote attendance; and
      4.   The member must assert one of the following three (3) reasons why he
or she is unable to physically attend the meeting:
         a.   The member cannot attend because of personal illness or
disability; or
         b.   The member cannot attend because of employment purposes or the
business of the village;
         c.   The member cannot attend because of a family or other emergency;
or
         d.   The member cannot attend due to an unexpected childcare
obligation.
   D.   Voting Procedures: After a roll call establishing that a quorum is
physically present, any member present may move that a member be permitted to
participate remotely, specifying the reason entitling the absent member to
participate remotely. All of the members physically present are permitted to
vote on whether remote participation will be allowed. The motion must be
approved by a vote of a majority of the quorum.
   E.   Adequate Equipment Required: The member participating remotely and
other members of the village must be able to communicate effectively, and
members of the audience must be able to hear all communications. Before
approving remote attendance at any meeting, the village shall provide equipment
adequate to accomplish this objective.
   F.   Minutes: Any member participating remotely shall be considered an off
site participant and counted as present by means of video or audio conference
for that meeting if the member is allowed to participate. The meeting minutes
shall also reflect and state specifically whether each member is physically
present, present by video, or present by audio means.
   G.   Rights Of Remote Member: A member permitted to participate remotely
will be able to express his or her comments during the meeting and participate
in the same capacity as those members physically present, subject to all
general meeting guidelines and procedures previously adopted and adhered to.
The remote member shall be heard, considered, and counted as to any vote taken.
Accordingly, the name of any remote member shall be called during any vote
taken, and his or her vote counted and recorded by the village clerk and placed
in the minutes for the corresponding meeting. A member participating remotely
may leave a meeting and return as in the case of any member.
   H.   Closed Meetings: A quorum of the village must be physically present at
any closed meeting. Members participating remotely shall otherwise be entitled
to participate in closed meetings by video or audio conference in the same
manner as at an open meeting.
   I.   Application To Committees, Boards And Commissions: This policy shall
apply to all committees, boards and commissions established by authority of the
village. However, when remote attendance is possible only by audio connection
and an off site member will be unable to view visual exhibits or demonstrations
which may influence a decision by the committee, board or commission, remote
attendance should not be approved. (Ord. 2008-02, 1-22-2008; amd. Ord. 11-7-
2024)
CHAPTER 6
MAYOR, BOARD OF TRUSTEES, AND MEETINGS
SECTION:
1-6-1: Election; Composition
1-6-2: Terms Of Office
1-6-3: Vacancies In Office
1-6-4: Salaries
1-6-5: Board Of Trustees Powers And Duties
1-6-6: Mayor
1-6-7: Meetings
1-6-8: Rules Governing Meetings
1-6-9: Procedure Of Meetings
1-6-10: Standing Committees
1-6-11: Committee Of The Whole
1-6-1: ELECTION; COMPOSITION:
The Village shall be governed by a Board of Trustees which shall be elected at
large and shall consist of a Mayor and six (6) Trustees. (Ord. 2009-33, 4-6-
2009)
1-6-2: TERMS OF OFFICE:
   A.   Trustees: The term of office of the Trustees shall be four (4) years
and until their successors are elected and have qualified. After the first
election, three (3) Trustees shall be elected by the electors of the Village
for a four (4) year term at the regular Village election held on the first
Tuesday in April of each odd numbered year, as provided by statute. The term of
office of newly elected Trustees shall commence at the first Village Board
meeting in May following the election provided that the McLean County Clerk has
certified the official election results, he or she has qualified, and taken the
oath of office; otherwise, the newly elected Trustee shall commence his or her
term of office at the first meeting after the official election results have
been certified by the McLean County Clerk, has been qualified and has taken the
oath of office after the first meeting in May.
   B.   Mayor: The term of office of the Mayor shall be four (4) years. He
shall be elected by the electors of the Village at the regular Village election
held on the first Tuesday in April 1981, and each fourth year thereafter. The
term of office of a newly elected Mayor shall commence at the first Village
Board meeting in May following the election provided that the McLean County
Clerk has certified the official election results, he or she has qualified, and
has taken the oath of office; otherwise, the newly elected Mayor shall commence
his or her term of office at the first meeting after the official election
results have been certified by the McLean County Clerk, has been qualified and
has taken the oath of office after the first meeting in May. (Ord. 2019-27, 6-
6-2019)
1-6-3: VACANCIES IN OFFICE:
Vacancy in the Office of Trustee or Mayor shall be filled as prescribed by the
Illinois Municipal Code. (Ord. 2009-33, 4-6-2009)
1-6-4: SALARIES:
The salaries of the Municipal elected officers shall be established as set
forth by ordinance. (Ord. 2009-33, 4-6-2009)
1-6-5: BOARD OF TRUSTEES POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The powers of the Village Board of Trustees shall be purely
legislative, except as may be otherwise provided by any other act or by any
other article of the Illinois Municipal Code.
   B.   In accordance with 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-45-5, the Board
of Trustees shall exercise the same powers and perform the same duties as the
City Council in cities.
   C.   The Board of Trustees shall pass ordinances, resolutions, and motions
in the same manner as a City Council.
   D.   The Board of Trustees shall approve for payment of all expenses and
liabilities of the Village. (Res. 2006-09, 5-1-2006)
1-6-6: MAYOR:
   A.   President Of Board Of Trustees: The Mayor shall be President of the
Board of Trustees as provided by statute. The President may be designated Mayor
of the Village. The Mayor shall be the presiding officer of all regular and
special meetings of the Village Board.
   B.   Powers And Duties:
      1.   Chief Executive Officer: The Mayor shall be the Chief Executive
Officer of the Village and shall perform all such duties as may be required of
him by statute or ordinance. He shall have general supervision over all the
executive officers of the Village and over all of the employees of the Village.
      2.   Designation Of Duties: The Mayor shall settle any question as to the
respective powers or duties of any appointed officer or employee of the
Village. He shall have the power to delegate to any such officer any duty which
is to be performed when no specific officer has been directed to perform the
duty.
      3.   Veto Powers:
         a.   Ordinances: The Mayor may veto any ordinance, in whole or in
part, by returning the ordinance, without signature, to the Board of Trustees
at the next regularly scheduled meeting after passage, together with his
written objections thereto. The Trustees then holding office shall, at the
regularly scheduled meeting after the meeting at which the Mayor submits his
written objections to the ordinance, reconsider the ordinance, and if, after
such reconsideration, two-thirds (2/3) of all the Trustees then holding office
vote to pass the ordinance, the ordinance shall go into effect.
         b.   Resolutions And Motions: The Mayor may veto all resolutions and
motions, in whole or in part, that create any liability against the Village,
that provide for the expenditure or appropriation of its monies, or that sell
any Village property by filing a written objection with the Board of Trustees
at the next regularly scheduled meeting after passage of the resolution or
motion. The Trustees then holding office shall, at the regularly scheduled
meeting after the meeting at which the Mayor submits his written objections to
the resolution or motion, reconsider the resolution or motion, and if, after
such reconsideration, two-thirds (2/3) of all the Trustees then holding office
vote to pass the resolution or motion, that resolution or motion shall go into
effect.
      4.   Suspension Of Officers Or Employees: The Mayor shall have the power
to suspend any officer or employee appointed by him on any formal charge
whenever he is of the opinion that the interests of the Village demand such
suspension. He shall report the reasons for such action to the Board at a
meeting to be held not less than five (5) days nor more than ten (10) days
after such suspension. The Board shall determine the final disposition of any
charge by dismissal or otherwise.
      5.   Licenses: The Mayor shall grant licenses for the purposes authorized
by this Code to such persons as he may deem proper, unless the Board shall
otherwise provide, and he may revoke the same for cause.
      6.   Signature: The Mayor shall sign all Village warrants, commissions,
permits and licenses granted by authority of the Board, except as otherwise
provided, and such other acts and deeds as law or ordinance may require his
official signature.
   C.   Mayor Or President Pro Tem; Temporary Chairperson:
      1.   Mayor Or President Pro Tem: If the Mayor or President is temporarily
absent because of an incapacity to perform official duties, but the incapacity
does not create a vacancy in the office, the Corporate Authorities shall elect
one of their members to act as Mayor or President Pro Tem. The Mayor or
President Pro Tem, during this absence or disability, shall perform the duties
and possess all the rights and powers of the Mayor or President but shall not
be entitled to vote both as Mayor or President Pro Tem and as Trustee.
      2.   Temporary Chairperson: In the absence of the Mayor, President,
acting Mayor or President, or Mayor or President Pro Tem, the Corporate
Authorities may elect one of their members to act as a temporary Chairperson.
The temporary Chairperson shall have only the powers of a presiding officer and
a right to vote only in the capacity as Trustee on any ordinance, resolution,
or motion. (Ord. 2009-33, 4-6-2009)
1-6-7: MEETINGS:
   A.   Regular Meetings: The Board of Trustees shall, unless otherwise ordered
by ordinance of the Board of Trustees, hold its regular meetings at the Village
Hall on the first and third Thursdays of each month at six thirty o’clock (6:
30) P.M., except when such date falls on a legal holiday, in which event, the
meeting shall be held on the next succeeding business day or at such other
times as the Board may prescribe by ordinance. Public notice of regular
meetings shall be given as required by the Open Meetings Act 1 .
   B.   Special Meetings:
      1.   The Mayor or any three (3) of the Trustees may call special meetings
of the Board of Trustees at any time 2 . The Clerk or his duly authorized
designee shall notify all members of the Board of Trustees of such meeting at
least forty eight (48) hours before the same is held, by delivering a written
notice stating the time and place of such meeting to each member personally or
by leaving the notice at his residence. Public notice of special meetings shall
be given as required by the Open Meetings Act 3 .
      2.   Whenever all of the members of the Board of Trustees are present at
any meeting at which a special meeting is scheduled, the requirement of notice
of the special meeting shall be deemed waived.
   C.   Committee Of The Whole Meetings: A Committee of the Whole meeting may
be called by the Mayor or by any three (3) Trustees 4 .
   D.   Open Meetings: All committee, Board, and Committee of the Whole
meetings, except those exempted by State Statute, shall be open to the public.
(Ord. 2009-35, 4-6-2009; amd. Ord. 2013-6, 2-7-2013; Ord. 2020-46, 6-18-2020)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 120/2.02, 120/2.03.
2 2. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-25.
3 3. 5 ILCS 120/2.02.
4 4. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-25.
1-6-8: RULES GOVERNING MEETINGS:
   A.   Quorum: A majority of the Corporate Authorities shall constitute a
quorum for the transaction of business. However, a smaller number shall have
the power to compel the attendance of absent members and to adjourn to such
time as they may designate.
   B.   Absent Trustees:
      1.   Summons Demanding Presence: In case of the want of a quorum at any
time and in case a majority of the Board of Trustees present shall direct the
Mayor or presiding officer to do so, the Mayor shall have served, by a police
officer of the Village, a summons on any absent Trustee demanding the immediate
presence of such Trustee at the meeting if he is able to attend.
      2.   Fine: Any Trustee who shall ignore such notice or who shall wilfully
fail to attend any regular or special meeting of the Board of Trustees without
good cause may be fined twenty five dollars ($25.00) upon a majority vote of
the Board of Trustees.
      3.   Nonfeasance Of Office: If any Trustee refuses to attend four (4)
meetings after receiving such notice, such Trustee shall be deemed guilty of
nonfeasance of office, and the Board of Trustees may, with the concurrence of
two-thirds (2/3) of all of the Board of Trustees, expel such Trustee, in which
case, his seat shall become vacant and shall be filled as any other vacancy as
provided by ordinance or State Statute.
   C.   Deliberations Of Board: The latest edition of "Robert's Rules of Order"
shall govern the deliberations of the Board of Trustees except when in conflict
with any of the provisions of Village ordinances or State Statutes 1 .
   D.   Suspension Of Rules: The rules of order, other than those prescribed by
statute, may be suspended at any time upon motion and affirmative roll call
vote of two-thirds (2/3) of all members of the Board of Trustees.
   E.   Question Of Rescinding Vote: No vote of the Board of Trustees shall be
reconsidered or rescinded at any special meeting thereof unless, at such
special meeting, there shall be present as many members as were present when
such vote was taken 2 .
   F.   Public Comment/Addressing A Public Body: All public meetings of any
public body of the Village of Heyworth shall allow for public comment subject
to the following:
      1.   Citizens may cordially address comments or concerns to the public
body as a whole for not more than three (3) minutes each about items pertaining
to the agenda.
      2.   The public comment period at any meeting shall not exceed two (2)
hours in total.
      3.   The person presiding over a meeting shall address the public
individually during public comment. After being addressed individually to
speak, individuals are requested to clearly state their name and, if
appropriate, whether they represent an organization or party.
      4.   Unruly or inappropriate behavior will not be allowed at a meeting.
Failure to adhere to appropriate behavior and etiquette may cause for cessation
of public comment of the individual(s) and possible removal.
      5.   Repetitious or disruptive comments may be limited.
      6.   Public comment at public body meetings should not be considered a
time for dialogue with individual members of the public body. Those wishing to
speak with an individual of a public body should do so outside the times of the
meeting.
      7.   The Mayor, in the case of a meeting of the Board of Trustees, or the
person presiding over a public body meeting may suspend the above rules in
order to allow for additional public comment if deemed appropriate.
   G.   Conduct And Recordings At Meetings:
      1.   All persons that attend a meeting or hearing of the Village shall
conduct themselves in an orderly manner and in such a manner so as to not
unreasonably interfere with the business at hand or overall decorum of such
meeting or hearing.
      2.   Recordings: Any person may record the proceedings at meetings
required to be open by the Illinois Open Meetings Act by tape, film or other
means subject to the following:
         a.   The means by which the recording is performed shall not be placed
or used in such a manner so as to unreasonably obstruct the view of other
persons at the meeting or invade the personal space of any such person;
         b.   The recording device does not emit an unreasonable sound or light
that interferes with the business at hand;
         c.   If a witness at an open meeting conducted by a commission,
administrative agency, or other tribunal refuses to testify if any portion of
his or her testimony is to be broadcast or televised or if motion pictures are
to be taken of the witness while testifying, then the public body holding the
meeting shall prohibit such recording during the testimony of the witness; this
exception applies to quasi-judicial proceedings only; or
         d.   Any other such reason as adopted by formal action of the Village
Board or as allowed by law.
   H.   Disturbing Meetings: It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb or
disrupt any meeting of the Board of Trustees or any committee thereof. Any
person violating the provisions of this subsection shall be fined not less than
twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for
each offense.
   I.   Passage Of Ordinances And Expenditure Of Monies: All ordinances and any
resolution or motion that creates any liability against the Village or for the
expenditure or appropriation of its monies and upon the question of the passage
of any other resolution or motion at the request of the member of the Board of
Trustees shall be taken by votes of yea, nay or present and shall be recorded
in the journal of its proceedings.
   J.   Placing Items For Action On An Agenda: The Mayor or any two (2)
Trustees may place an action for vote on an agenda of a Board meeting. The two
(2) Trustees shall contact the Village Clerk or his/her designee with the
specifics of the action to be taken no less than forty eight (48) hours in
advance of the meeting in order for it to be included on the next Board meeting
agenda. (Ord. 2009-35, 4-6-2009; amd. Ord. 2014-22, 9-4-2014; Ord. 2015-47, 11-
19-2015; Ord. 2020-46, 6-18-2020)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-15.
2 2. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-55.
1-6-9: PROCEDURE OF MEETINGS:
   A.   Board Of Trustees Meeting: If a quorum is present, a meeting of the
Board of Trustees shall proceed substantially in the following order:
      1.   The minutes of the last meeting shall be reviewed, any amendments
deemed necessary shall be made and approval shall occur of the same. The
minutes standing shall be considered approved unless objected to.
      2.   Consent agenda/approval of submitted items and audit of fund
expenditures.
      3.   Reports of officers and officials.
      4.   Citizens recognized/public comment.
      5.   Old business.
      6.   Reports of committees.
      7.   New business.
      8.   Approval of action items including ordinances, resolutions and
motions. Action items cannot be approved unless posted and published by law and
not less than forty eight (48) hours prior to vote on the item unless otherwise
proscribed by statute.
      9.   Executive session (if needed).
      10.   Adjournment.
   B.   Committee Meetings: If a quorum is present, a committee meeting of the
Village shall proceed substantially in the manner set forth in the agenda
posted for that committee meeting.
   C.   Deviation Of Procedure: The procedure of meetings as listed above may
be deviated in order to improve the conduct of business of the public body.
(Ord. 2009-35, 4-6-2009; amd. Ord. 2014-22, 9-4-2014; Ord. 2020-46, 6-18-2020)
1-6-10: STANDING COMMITTEES:
   A.   Creation; Dissolution: The Mayor, with the advice and consent of the
Board of Trustees, may, by ordinance, create or dissolve any standing committee
deemed necessary and in the best interest of the Village.
   B.   Selection; Chairperson: The Board of Trustees, by a majority vote,
shall select the members of all standing committees and designate a Chairperson
for each committee every two (2) years at or after the first meeting in May, or
as soon thereafter as is practicable, following a general election of Trustees.
In case of a tie, the Mayor shall issue a vote when determining the members and
Chairperson of standing committees. The members and duties of the standing
committees may be amended at any time as deemed necessary by the Mayor and
Board of Trustees.
   C.   Duties And Functions:
      1.   The Mayor and Board of Trustees, by majority vote, shall mutually
designate the duties of the standing committees at or after the first meeting
in May following a general election of Trustees. In case of a tie, the Mayor
shall issue a vote when determining the duties of the standing committees.
      2.   The primary function of standing committees is one of policy
recommendation. The actual administration of a particular Municipal activity or
department remains the responsibility of the administrative official in charge
thereof. Committees shall conduct investigations, make detailed studies of
pending proposals, keep in close contact with the work of the various Municipal
departments and officials, perform detail work when it is not feasible to pass
upon such work at a meeting of the Board of Trustees, submit recommendations to
the Board of Trustees for official action, or any other authority prescribed by
ordinance.
   D.   Committee Procedure: Pursuant to and consistent with this section, the
following is the Village policy regarding committee procedure:
      1.   From time to time, various issues and situations are presented to
the Corporate Authorities of the Village.
      2.   If possible and practical, such issues shall be directed to the
appropriate committee addressing such issues. If there is not an appropriate
committee to address the issue, then the Mayor and/or Board of Trustees shall
collectively make a determination as to what shall be done to address the issue
or situation.
      3.   The committee shall place the issue on the agenda for the next
committee meeting and debate/discuss the issue.
      4.   a.   The committee, by a majority vote, shall have the prima facie
(appearance of) authority necessary to use appointed agents (i.e., attorney,
engineer, etc.) and Village employees (i.e., Administrative Assistants,
Superintendents, etc.) to gather information, perform research and other minor
tasks to aid the committee in addressing the issue.
         b.   Should a situation arise as to whether the use of an appointed
agent or Village employee pursuant to subsection D4a of this section is
authorized or permitted, said appointed agent or Village employee shall be
allowed to contact the Mayor or wait until the next Board of Trustees meeting,
whichever is sooner, before acting pursuant to the direction of the committee.
If said appointed official or Village employee contacts the Mayor, the Mayor's
direction shall be final on said appointed official or Village employee until
the next full Board of Trustees meeting.
      5.   The committee shall make a report or verbally state an opinion,
through its Chairperson, at the Board of Trustees meeting.
      6.   The full Board of Trustees shall then have the ability to accept,
reject or otherwise act on that opinion and issue.
   E.   Trustee And Committee Excess Or Abuse Of Authority: Should any Trustee
or committee exceed the authority provided for in this section, that Trustee or
those Trustees shall be subject to reprimand as provided for in the Village
Ethics Ordinance which is located in chapter 12 of this title and as provided
for in any other applicable local, State, or Federal law.
   F.   Committees Enumerated: The current standing committees of the Village
Board of Trustees are as follows:
      1.   Economic Development, Planning and Zoning.
      2.   Parks and Recreation.
      3.   Streets and Public Utilities.
   G.   Purpose And Responsibilities: The purpose and responsibilities of each
standing committee shall be as follows:
      1.   Economic Development, Planning And Zoning Committee:
         a.   The Economic Development, Planning and Zoning Committee shall be
the committee providing oversight over:
            (1)   Planning And Economic Development: Review and recommend
approval, modification or denial of all aspects of subdivision creation,
including, but not limited to, streets, water, and sewer infrastructure
oversight; the modification or re-subdividing of land; the planning for future
growth and development in the corporate limits and extraterritorial authority;
and other economic development;
            (2)   Real Estate: The purchase, sale or lease of Village property
or potential Village property; review existing real property issues currently
within the Village, such as areas where easements, rights-of-way, and other
encumbrances need to be obtained for existing infrastructure within the
Village; and after locating existing areas of need, planning for and working
through ways to remedy and correct those areas of need, such as obtaining
easements, rights-of-way and other real property matters to correct existing
issues as well as improve the current real property areas of the Village for
the betterment of the community;
            (3)   TIF And Business Development Districts: Along with the
administration and any TIF and/or Business Development District consultants of
the Village, coordinate TIF and Business Development agreements and oversee the
formation and development of proposed TIF and Business Development districts;
            (4)   Annexations: Review proposed annexations and annexation
agreements, and analyze and provide recommendation for the possible annexation
of nearby property;
            (5)   Planning Commission: Assist in the formation and general
oversight of planning commission matters of the Village;
            (6)   Building Construction And Property Maintenance: Along with
the administrating officials of the Village, review new building construction
matters or the remodel, reconstruction, repair or maintenance of existing
structures;
            (7)   Zoning: General matters relating to zoning in the
jurisdiction of the Village that are not under the purview of the Zoning Board
of Appeals or Zoning Administrating Official;
            (8)   Code Compliance Oversight: Review and give recommendation as
to code compliance ordinances, violations presented to the committee, and other
issues related to code compliance not under the purview of the Code Compliance
Officer or other appropriate administrating official;
            (9)   Business Licenses: Review and recommend regulations
affiliated with business licenses in the Village; and
            (10)   Code Review Of Health And Sanitation, Building, Zoning,
Subdivision Regulation And Annexation Codes: Review, at least once annually,
and make recommendations for amendment, if necessary, for the Village Codes
related to health and sanitation codes, which are currently located in title 5;
building codes, which are currently located in title 10; zoning regulations,
which are currently located in title 11; subdivision regulations, which are
currently located in title 12; and annexations, which are currently located in
title 13.
         b.   The Economic Development, Planning, and Zoning Committee shall
not be responsible for providing oversight over:
            (1)   Streets And Public Utilities: The installation, maintenance,
or planning of existing streets, public utilities and infrastructure in
existing developments or subdivisions;
            (2)   Security Issues: The enforcement of security matters of the
Village may be the responsibility of the Police Department or the
administration of the Village;
            (3)   Code Compliance And Enforcement Of Nuisance And Ordinance
Violations: The enforcement of nuisance and ordinance violations that are the
responsibility of the administration and/or the appropriate administrating
officials of the Village.
            (4)   Duties And Responsibilities Of The Zoning Board Of Appeals Or
Planning Commission: Shall not perform the duties or responsibilities of the
Village's Zoning Board of Appeals or Planning Commission.
      2.   Parks And Recreation:
         a.   The Parks and Recreation Committee shall be the committee
providing oversight over:
            (1)   Parks And Playgrounds: The review and recommendation of the
equipment, landscape, and improvements of the current and future parks of the
Village;
            (2)   Special Events: Help coordinate and making recommendations
for the entertainment and special events that occur in the Village that are
conducted by the Village if such authority is specifically authorized by the
Village Board;
            (3)   Green Initiatives And Ecology: The review and recommendation
of "green" initiatives and ecology for the Village;
            (4)   Conservation And Habitation: The review and recommendation of
ways to improve conservation and habitation throughout the Village;
            (5)   Animal Control: The review and recommendation of ways to
improve animal control or when there is need to address new animal control
considerations of the Village; and
            (6)   Code Review Of Parks And Recreation And Environmental Codes:
Review, at least once annually, the Village Codes related to parks and
recreation, which are currently located in chapter 5 of title 8 of this code,
and animal control regulations currently located in chapter 2 of title 6 of
this code.
         b.   The Parks and Recreation Committee shall not be responsible for
providing oversight over:
            (1)   Code Compliance And Enforcement Of Nuisance And Ordinance
Violations: The enforcement of nuisance and ordinance violations, which is the
responsibility of the administration and or the appropriate administrating
officials of the Village.
      3.   Streets And Public Utilities:
         a.   The Streets and Public Utilities Committee shall be the committee
providing oversight over:
            (1)   Streets, Alleys And Sidewalks: After streets, alleys, rights-
of-way and sidewalks have been dedicated to the Village, or for property
currently owned by the Village, providing recommendation for the maintenance,
construction, reconstruction or planning over streets, alleys, rights-of-way
and sidewalks in the Village, including contracts related to improvements
thereto;
            (2)   Driveways, Culverts And Drainage: Along with the public works
supervisor(s), providing recommendation for ways to plan, improve or maintain
drainage, driveway approaches on Village rights-of-way only, and culverts
throughout the Village;
            (3)   Storm Sewer Installations: The oversight and installation of
storm sewer maintenance, installations, or finance related to underground storm
sewer installations.
            (4)   Public Utilities And Rights-of-Way: Along with the Village
public works supervisor(s), providing recommendations for ways to improve and
maintain the rights-of-way and locations of public utilities in the Village;
and
            (5)   Water Treatment Plant: Along with public works supervisor(s)
and administration of the Village, review and provide recommendations for the
maintenance and improvements related to the water treatment plant(s) of the
Village, including contracts related thereto;
            (6)   Wells, Towers And Mains: Along with public works supervisor
(s) and the administration of the Village, review and provide recommendations
for the maintenance and improvements related to the public wells, water towers,
and water main systems of the Village including contracts related thereto;
            (7)   Sewerage Plant And System: Along with the public works
supervisor(s) and the administration of the Village, review and provide
recommendations for the maintenance and improvements related to the sewerage
plants and sewerage system of the Village, including contracts related thereto;
            (8)   Garbage And Recycling Management: Along with the
administration of the Village, review and provide recommendation for ways to
improve the garbage and recycling collection and management in the Village,
including contracts related thereto; and
            (9)   Review Of Accidents: In conjunction with the administration
of the Village, review accidents subject the Accident Investigation Policy of
the Village;
            (10)   Code Review Of Public Ways, Public Utilities, Garbage:
Review, at least once annually, the Village Codes related to the public ways
and property, which are currently located in title 8 of this code; the water,
sewer, drainage, streets and garbage ordinances of the Village, which are
currently located in title 9 of this code.
         b.   The Streets and Public Utilities Committee shall not be
responsible for providing oversight over:
            (1)   Code Compliance And Enforcement Of Nuisance And Ordinance
Violations: The enforcement of nuisance and ordinance violations, which is the
responsibility of the administration and or the appropriate administrating
officials of the Village.
            (2)   Streets, Alleys, Sidewalks, Drainage And Public Utilities
During Subdivision Creation: The oversight and negotiation of streets, alleys,
sidewalks, drainage and public utilities during subdivision creation.
      4.   Budgets: On or before February 1 of each calendar year, each
standing committee may submit a written estimated budget of funds that is
suggested to be allocated for projects or items addressed by such committee
during the next Village fiscal year to the Budget Officer and the Committee of
the Whole for Finance and Audits of the Village. Each committee may also
hereinafter create and submit to the Committee of the Whole for Finance and
Audit a five (5) year and twenty (20) year plan of proposed capital improvement
projects and major expenses by February 1 after the date of adoption of this
section and review and amend these plans, if necessary, on or before February 1
of each year thereafter.
      5.   Meetings: Each standing committee shall hold such public meetings as
may be necessary to attend to all matters referred to such committee. The time
and place of all public meetings shall be determined by the Chairperson of each
standing committee. Special meetings of each standing committee may be called
at any time by the Chairperson or any two (2) members of each standing
committee. Public notice of committee meetings shall be given in accordance
with the Open Meetings Act. (Ord. 2009-51, 5-4-2009; amd. Ord. 2011-32, 7-18-
2011; Ord. 2019-26, 6-6-2019; Ord. 2019-58, 10-17-2019; Ord. 2023-32, 5-18-
2023)
1-6-11: COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE:
   A.   Creation: There is hereby created a Committee of the Whole which shall
be composed of the Mayor and all members of the Board of Trustees.
   B.   Purpose; Intent: The purpose and intent of Committee of the Whole
meetings shall be primarily for discussion of items intended to be brought
before the Village Board of Trustees and various matters which require a
presentation and/or upon which discussion is anticipated, but not for action on
ordinances, resolutions or motions.
   C.   Meetings: The Board of Trustees may meet as a Committee of the Whole
when necessary. Public notice shall be given as required by the Open Meetings
Act 1 . The rules governing meetings stated in section
1-6-8 of this chapter shall apply. (Ord. 2013-6, 2-7-2013)
 
Notes

CHAPTER 7
VILLAGE OFFICERS AND PERSONNEL; GENERAL PROVISIONS

1-7-1: COMPENSATION:
   A.   Salaries: The salaries of the appointed officers and officials of the
village shall be as established in the annual wage and salary ordinance adopted
by the Village Board of Trustees.
   B.   Mileage Rate: The standard mileage reimbursement rate at the IRS
standard mileage reimbursement rate. (Res. 2008-07, 2-4-2008; amd. Ord. 2009-
33, 4-6-2009; Ord. 2009-134, 12-21-2009, eff. 1-1-2010; 2011 Code; Ord. 2024-

CHAPTER 8
APPOINTIVE VILLAGE OFFICIALS
ARTICLE A. VILLAGE CLERK
SECTION:
1-8A-1: Appointment, Term And Compensation
1-8A-2: Bond And Oath
1-8A-3: Qualifications
1-8A-4: Powers And Duties Enumerated
1-8A-5: Duties Concerning Documents
1-8A-6: Additional Duties
1-8A-1: APPOINTMENT, TERM AND COMPENSATION:
The Village Clerk shall be appointed by the Mayor, with the advice and consent
of the Board of Trustees. The appointment shall become effective commencing at
the first regularly scheduled meeting following the general Municipal election
for Mayor in the Village and shall be to a four (4) year term unless removed by
the Mayor or by resolution of the Board of Trustees prior to that date, per
State Statute. Compensation shall be determined by the Board of Trustees as
outlined in the annual budget. (Ord. 2009-13, 2-17-2009; amd. 2011 Code)
1-8A-2: BOND AND OATH:
Before entering upon the duties of office, the Village Clerk shall execute a
bond with sureties in such amount to be fixed by resolution and to be approved
by the Board of Trustees, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the
Clerk's duties as set forth herein or by statute, and conditioned upon the
indemnification of the Village for any loss by reason of any neglect of duty or
any requirement of the Clerk. The Clerk shall take the oath of office as
prescribed by statute. (Ord. 2009-13, 2-17-2009)
1-8A-3: QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   Residency: Shall reside within twenty five (25) miles of the Village
corporate limits unless otherwise specified by an agreement with the Board of
Trustees. (Ord. 2017-40, 5-18-2017)
1-8A-4: POWERS AND DUTIES ENUMERATED:
The Village Clerk shall have all the powers and perform all the duties now or
hereafter provided by the laws of the State of Illinois and the ordinances of
the Village. The Village Clerk shall, among other things, have the following
duties:
   A.   Office: Keep an office at the Village Hall or such other place
appointed by the Village Board of Trustees.
   B.   Attend Board Meetings: Attend all meetings of the Board of Trustees and
take minutes of all its proceedings.
   C.   Records: Record such minutes, together with all ordinances passed by
the Board of Trustees, in books to be kept for that purpose.
   D.   Publications: Publish all proceedings of the Board of Trustees and all
ordinances required by law to be published.
   E.   Notices: Serve all notices, either by personal service, by publication
or by posting, required by law or the order of the Village Board or the Mayor,
unless such notices are expressly ordered to be served by some other person.
   F.   Elections: Notify and declare the results of any election or
appointment to office, notify all persons elected or appointed to any Village
office of their election or appointment, and unless such persons shall
respectively qualify within ten (10) days after such notice, notify that the
office has become vacant.
   G.   Oath Of Office: Administer the oath of office to each such person so
elected or appointed; except, that the Mayor shall administer such oath of
office to the Clerk.
   H.   Filings: File all ordinances, communications, receipts and documents
required to be filed and arrange the same in systematic order for ready
reference.
   I.   Seal: Keep the Corporate Seal of the Village and affix the same to all
papers which require it.
   J.   Custodian Of Records: Be the custodian and keeper of all the books,
records, ordinances and papers of the Village, except as otherwise provided by
law or ordinance.
   K.   Evidence: Make copies of any papers in the Clerk's Office and
transcripts from journals and other records certified under the Corporate Seal
for use in evidence when required.
   L.   Tax Levy: File or cause to be filed a certified copy of each Tax Levy
Ordinance with the County Clerk within the time required by law.
   M.   Records Of Terms Of Office Of Officials: Maintain a record of the date
of commencement and expiration of the term of office of each elected Village
official and of each appointed Village official or officer. (Ord. 2009-13, 2-
17-2009; amd. Ord. 2017-40, 5-18-2017)
1-8A-5: DUTIES CONCERNING DOCUMENTS:
   A.   The Village Clerk shall be the custodian of all documents belonging to
the Village which are not assigned to the custody of some other officer. The
Village Clerk shall keep and maintain a proper index to all documents and
records kept by the Clerk for ready access and use.
   B.   The Village Clerk shall keep a full record of all licenses granted,
transferred or revoked by the Village Board of Trustees or the Mayor, or under
their authority, with the date that the same were granted, transferred or
revoked, and if revoked, the cause of revocation, with the number and the full
names and residences of applicants for such licenses. These shall be kept in a
book along with bonds and the names of the sureties. All petitions or other
communications addressed to the Board of Trustees shall be received by the
Village Clerk and read at the next meeting of the Board of Trustees succeeding
their receipt, unless otherwise ordered by the Mayor and/or the Board of
Trustees. The Clerk shall, without delay, deliver to the officers of the
Village, and to any committee of the Board of Trustees, all communications
referred to such officers or committees by the Mayor or the Board of Trustees.
   C.   The Village Clerk shall, without delay, deliver to the Mayor all
ordinances or resolutions which may require approval or other action by the
Mayor, with all papers on which the same were founded. (Ord. 2009-13, 2-17-
2009; amd. Ord. 2017-40, 5-18-2017)
1-8A-6: ADDITIONAL DUTIES:
In addition to the duties provided in this article, the Village Clerk shall
perform such other duties and functions as may be required by the Mayor,
statute, or ordinance, or by resolution of the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2009-
13, 2-17-2009; amd. Ord. 2017-40, 5-18-2017)
ARTICLE B. DEPUTY VILLAGE CLERK
SECTION:
1-8B-1: Created; Appointment, Term And Compensation
1-8B-2: Bond And Oath
1-8B-3: Qualifications
1-8B-4: Powers And Duties
1-8B-1: CREATED; APPOINTMENT, TERM AND COMPENSATION:
There is hereby created the Office of Deputy Village Clerk. The Village Clerk,
when authorized by resolution by the Board of Trustees, shall appoint a Deputy
Village Clerk whose term shall not exceed the term of Office of the Village
Clerk. The salary of the Deputy Village Clerk shall be determined by the Board
of Trustees as outlined in the annual budget. (Ord. 2009-12, 2-17-2009; amd.
2011 Code)
1-8B-2: BOND AND OATH:
The position of Deputy Clerk shall be required to have the same bond and oath
as the position of Village Clerk. (Ord. 2009-12, 2-17-2009)
1-8B-3: QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   Residency: Shall reside within twenty five (25) miles of the Village
corporate limits unless otherwise specified by an agreement with the Board of
Trustees. (Ord. 2017-41, 5-18-2017)
1-8B-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The Deputy Clerk shall have the power and duty to execute all documents
required by any law or ordinance to be executed by the Village Clerk and affix
the Seal of the Village whenever required. When signing any documents, the
Deputy Clerk shall sign the name of the Village Clerk followed by the word "by"
and the Deputy Clerk's own name and the words "Deputy Clerk".
   B.   The powers and duties of the Deputy Clerk shall only be exercised by
the Deputy Clerk in the absence of the Village Clerk, and only when direction
has been given by the Village Clerk to exercise such power or the Board of
Trustees has determined by resolution that the Village Clerk is temporarily or
permanently incapacitated to perform such function.
   C.   The Deputy Clerk shall perform such other duties and functions as may
be required by the Mayor, statute, or ordinance, or by resolution of the Board
of Trustees. (Ord. 2009-12, 2-17-2009; amd. Ord. 2017-41, 5-18-2017)
ARTICLE C. VILLAGE TREASURER
SECTION:
1-8C-1: Created; Appointment, Term And Compensation
1-8C-2: Bond And Oath
1-8C-3: Qualifications
1-8C-4: Powers And Duties
1-8C-5: Deposit Of Funds
1-8C-6: Special Assessment Funds
1-8C-7: Access To Financial Records
1-8C-1: CREATED; APPOINTMENT, TERM AND COMPENSATION:
There is hereby created the Office of Village Treasurer. The Village Treasurer
shall be appointed by the Mayor, with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees. The appointment shall become effective commencing at the first
regularly scheduled meeting following the general Municipal election for Mayor
in the Village and shall be to a four (4) year term unless removed by the Mayor
prior to that date. Compensation shall be determined by the Board of Trustees
as outlined in the annual budget. (Ord. 2009-14, 2-17-2009; amd. 2011 Code;
Ord. 2018-48, 8-16-2018)
1-8C-2: BOND AND OATH:
Before entering upon the duties of office, the Village Treasurer shall execute
a bond with sureties in such amount to be fixed by resolution and to be
approved by the Board of Trustees, conditioned upon the faithful performance of
the Treasurer's duties as set forth herein or by statute and conditioned upon
the indemnification of the Village for any loss by reason of any neglect of
duty or any requirement of Treasurer. The Village Treasurer shall take the oath
of office as prescribed by statute. (Ord. 2009-14, 2-17-2009)
1-8C-3: QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   The Village Treasurer must have the following qualifications:
      1.   Education, Experience and Skills:
         a.   Education and Training: Education and/or training and experience
in finance, auditing, accounting, or similar experience or education with
preference for a bachelor's degree or higher in accounting, finance, or similar
field;
         b.   Analytical skills; ability to solve finance problems, exercise
sound judgment and initiative; ability to work independently;
         c.   Ability to establish and maintain effective working relationships
with other employees, agencies, public officials and the general public; and
         d.   Ability to communicate effectively both orally and in writing;
ability to make public presentations.
      2.   Mandatory Physical Requirements: The Village Treasurer must be able
to:
         a.   Endurance/Moving About: Periodic. Physically move from location
to location for brief periods.
         b.   Endurance/Overall strength: Light work. Exert force and/or lift
or carry objects weighing up to twenty (20) pounds periodically.
