         c.   Sitting: Frequent. Be able to sit for extended periods.
         d.   Pushing/Pulling: Periodic. Push by exerting force on an object so
that it moves away from the force or worker and/or pull by exerting force on an
object so that it moves toward the force or worker.
         e.   Balancing: Periodic. Maintain body equilibrium to prevent falling
when walking, standing, crouching, or sitting.
         f.   Bending/Stooping: Periodic. Stoop by bending the body downward or
forward by flexing the spine at the waist, and/or bend by extending the spine
backward or from side to side.
         g.   Kneeling/Crouching: Periodic. Kneel by bending the legs at the
knees to come to rest on the knee or knees, and/or crouch by bending the body
downward and forward by bending the legs and spine.
         h.   Reaching: Constantly. Extend hands and arms in any direction.
         i.   Handling: Constantly. Seize, hold, grasp, turn or otherwise work
with the hand or hands.
         j.   Rotation: Frequently. Twist and turn the spine or a ball and
socket joint such as the shoulder or hip.
         k.   Talking: Constantly. Express or exchange ideas by means of the
spoken word to impart oral information to Village employees or officials or to
the public and convey detailed spoken instructions to other workers accurately,
loudly or quickly.
         l.   Hearing: Constantly. Perceive the nature of sounds by the ear.
         m.   Seeing: Constantly. Perceive the nature of sights by the eyes.
         n.   Reading: Ability to read various reports, financial documents,
memorandums and many other items.
         o.   Writing: Ability to write reports, financial statements, graphs
and charts, tax documents and other such documents necessary for the operation.
         p.   Miscellaneous: Such other reasonable physical and mental
abilities that may be required to carry out the position.
      3.   Residency: Shall reside within twenty-five (25) miles of the village
corporate limits unless otherwise specified by an agreement with the board of
trustees. (Ord. 2017-42, 5-18-2017; amd. Ord. 2018-48, 8-16-2018; Ord. 2022-
68, 11-21-2022)
1-8C-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The village treasurer shall have all the powers and perform all the duties now
or hereafter provided by the laws of the state of Illinois and the ordinances
of the village. The village treasurer shall, among other things, have the
following duties:
   A.   Essential Functions:
      1.   Monies: Receive all monies due or belonging to the village.
      2.   Warrants: Keep and pay all orders or warrants, including special
assessments, other bonds and interest coupons authorized by the board of
trustees and duly executed by the proper officers of the village. Each warrant
must have a description that includes the date, amount, number, the fund from
which it is paid, the date when paid, and the payee.
      3.   Books Of Accounting: Keep suitable books of account of the village
financial transactions, including from whom and on what account funds have been
received and a record of all monies paid out, including to whom and on what
account or fund and for what purpose the payment was made. The books shall be
balanced at least monthly and shall be at all times open to examination by the
mayor or board of trustees.
      4.   Accounts: Keep a separate account with each fund or appropriation
stating at the head of each account the amount appropriated and giving the
several debits and credits, as well as create, manage, and reconcile accounts.
      5.   General Ledger: Keep a general ledger by funds showing the
activities and transactions affecting each fund including the necessary
accruals for annual reports and other purposes.
      6.   Water And Sewer Accounts: Keep proper records and accounts in which
complete and correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the
water and sewerage systems. The annual audit shall be made by an independent
auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and disbursements of the
water and sewerage systems.
      7.   Reports: File a monthly report under oath to the mayor and board of
trustees. The report shall include the total receipts and disbursements for
each account or fund from commencement of the fiscal year to date; the amount
budgeted and the amount appropriated; and the amount under expended or over
expended in each account or fund for the current fiscal year. The report shall
be filed in the office of the village clerk and a summary provided to the board
of trustees. All canceled vouchers and invoices covering all transactions set
forth in the report shall be retained by the village treasurer.
      8.   Annual Review: Provide, within one hundred eighty (180) days of the
end of the fiscal year, an annual review of a full and detailed account of all
receipts and disbursements during the preceding fiscal year to the board of
trustees for approval. The account shall show the state of the treasury at the
close of the fiscal year. The account shall also show the aggregate revenues
received during the fiscal year in each fund and will also show the aggregate
disbursements for each fund and each budget category within a fund. Such
account shall be provided to the village clerk for publication and to file for
public inspection in the office of the village clerk or as required by law.
      9.   Filing Of Accounts: All accounts shall be filed with the village
clerk, who shall cause to be published at least once in a newspaper of general
circulation in the village, a notice of the filing of such accounts. A copy of
such accounts, as filed with the village clerk and bearing the affidavit
thereof, shall be filed with the county collector before September 1 of each
year, or as soon thereafter as the same is available for filing. The procedure
for the preparation, filing and publication of the annual account shall be
deemed to be in compliance of the Illinois municipal code. Compliance with the
provisions of this subsection shall constitute full authority to the county
authorities to disburse all appropriate tax monies to the village.
      10.   Tax Levy and Tax Documents: Prepare and file the annual tax levy
and other such documents that may be necessary to levy or collect the taxes of
the Village or to implement desired taxes of the Village.
      11.   Multiple Positions; Office Staff Responsibilities: The Village
Treasurer may be a position that the person filling the position has other
responsibilities or fulfills another position in addition to being Village
Treasurer, such as being an office staff or office manager. This shall be
determined at the time of hire. If the treasurer has another position that is
compatible with the treasurer position, those responsibilities shall be
incorporated into this job description; however, it shall not convert that
person to a contracted or employee position and this person shall remain an
appointed official.
      12.   Budget Officer: Is generally intended to hold the positions of both
Treasurer and Budget Officer (see Section
1-8J-1 et seq. of the Village Code) unless a Budget Officer is otherwise duly
appointed by the Mayor and Board of Trustees.
      13.   Tax-Increment Financing (TIF) and Business Development District
Analysis and Implementation: Working with the Village Administrator and any
consultants, assist in the financial analysis and accounting of the Village's
TIF and Business Development districts, if any. This includes, but is not
limited to, preparation of spreadsheets, financial analysis of redevelopment
agreements, projections of tax growth and distributions, and other such
financial matters that may assist and further these districts.
      14.   Investments: In consultation and collaboration with the Village
Administrator and relevant committees of the Village Board, invest assets of
the Village according to the Village's investment policy and securing proper
public securities of all uninsured or underinsured assets.
      15.   Bonds and Loans: Assist or act on behalf of staff and the village
board of trustees with the preparation and negotiation of loan documents as
well as assist with the satisfaction of any requirements of any bond ordinance
or loan agreement approved by the Village Board of Trustees.
      16.   Audits: Provide any relevant information to the village auditor and
implement any recommended changes to the general ledger related to such audit.
      17.   Transfer Funds: Transfer funds according to the village
appropriation ordinances.
      18.   Payroll Clerk: Assist with making timely payments of payroll and
benefit expenses and payroll taxes as previously authorized by the Village
Board of Trustees.
      19.   Payments: Make payments to vendors or other third parties after
approval by the Village Board of Trustees.
      20.   Grants: Assist in the application for, adherence to, and reporting
of various local, state, federal and private grants that may assist the Village
operations.
   B.   Non-Essential Functions:
      1.   General Filing: Assist with the filing and record keeping of the
Village.
      2.   Customer Service: Assist with customer service including, but not
limited to, answering phones, greeting and assisting persons that come to the
Village Hall, and other such items necessary to assist with the Village
operations.
      3.   Other Duties: Perform such other duties and functions as may be
required by a supervisor, ordinance of the village, or laws of the state of
Illinois. (Ord. 2009-14, 2-17-2009; amd. Ord. 2017-42, 5-18-2017; Ord. 2018-48,
8-16-2018; Ord. 2022-68, 11-21-2022)
1-8C-5: DEPOSIT OF FUNDS:
The Village Treasurer shall review and approve the deposit of Village funds in
such depositories as may be selected from time to time as provided by law or by
Village ordinance. The Treasurer shall review and approve procedures for the
handling of Village funds to assure that Village monies are kept separate and
distinct from the monies of any individual and to assure that no individual may
make private or personal use of any Village monies. (Ord. 2009-14, 2-17-2009;
amd. Ord. 2017-42, 5-18-2017)
1-8C-6: SPECIAL ASSESSMENT FUNDS:
All monies received on any special assessment shall be placed in a special fund
to be applied only to the principal and interest payment of the improvement,
bond or vouchers for which they were received. The monies shall be used for no
other purpose unless to reimburse the Village for the monies expended for such
improvement. Payment on bonds or vouchers shall be made in accordance with the
laws of the State of Illinois. The Treasurer shall review the books and
accounts to assure that proper prorations in payments of principal and interest
can be made and ascertained and unpaid receivable balances calculated. (Ord.
2009-14, 2-17-2009; amd. Ord. 2017-42, 5-18-2017)
1-8C-7: ACCESS TO FINANCIAL RECORDS:
Any agency of the State of Illinois or member of the Board of Trustees shall
have access to and be able to review and examine any financial books,
documents, papers and records of the Village except those precluded by law.
(Ord. 2009-14, 2-17-2009; amd. Ord. 2017-42, 5-18-2017)
ARTICLE D. DEPUTY VILLAGE TREASURER
SECTION:
1-8D-1: Created; Appointment, Term And Compensation
1-8D-2: Bond And Oath
1-8D-3: Qualifications
1-8D-4: Powers And Duties
1-8D-1: CREATED; APPOINTMENT, TERM AND COMPENSATION:
There is hereby created the Office of Deputy Village Treasurer. The Village
Treasurer, with the advice and consent of the Mayor and when authorized by
resolution of the Board of Trustees, shall appoint a Deputy Village Treasurer
or Deputy Village Treasurers whose term(s) shall not exceed the term of Office
of the Village Treasurer. The salary of the Deputy Village Treasurer(s) shall
be determined by the Board of Trustees as outlined in the annual budget. (Ord.
2009-60, 5-12-2009; amd. 2011 Code)
1-8D-2: BOND AND OATH:
The position of Deputy Village Treasurer shall be required to have the same
bond and oath as the position of Village Treasurer. (Ord. 2009-60, 5-12-2009)
1-8D-3: QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   Residency: Shall reside within twenty five (25) miles of the Village
corporate limits if full-time and fifty (50) miles of the Village corporate
limits if part-time unless otherwise specified by an agreement with the Board
of Trustees. (Ord. 2017-43, 5-18-2017)
1-8D-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   A Deputy Village Treasurer shall have all the powers and duties of the
Village Treasurer. When signing any documents, the Deputy Village Treasurer
shall sign the name of the Village Treasurer followed by the word "by" and the
Deputy Village Treasurer's own name and the words "Deputy Treasurer".
   B.   The powers and duties of the Deputy Treasurer shall only be exercised
by the Deputy Village Treasurer in the absence of the Village Treasurer, and
only when direction has been given by the Village Treasurer to exercise such
power or if the Board of Trustees has determined by resolution that the Village
Treasurer is temporarily or permanently incapacitated to perform such function.
   C.   The Deputy Village Treasurer shall perform such other duties and
functions as may be required by the Mayor or statute, or by motion, resolution
or ordinance of the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2009-60, 5-12-2009; amd. Ord.
2017-43, 5-18-2017)
ARTICLE E. VILLAGE MARSHAL (CHIEF OF POLICE)
SECTION:
1-8E-1: Created; Appointment, Term And Compensation
1-8E-2: Oath And Qualifications
1-8E-3: Powers And Duties
1-8E-1: CREATED; APPOINTMENT, TERM AND COMPENSATION:
There is hereby created the Office of Village Marshal, which shall be known as
the Chief of the Police Department. The Chief of Police shall be appointed by
the Mayor, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. The
appointment of the Chief of Police shall become effective commencing at the
first regularly scheduled meeting following the general Municipal election for
Mayor in the Village and shall be effective through and including the date of
expiration of the term of the Mayor unless the Chief of Police is discharged by
the Mayor or by resolution of the Board of Trustees prior to that date. The
Chief of Police shall receive such salary as is determined by the Board of
Trustees as outlined in the annual budget. (Ord. 2009-15, 2-17-2009; amd. 2011
Code)
1-8E-2: OATH AND QUALIFICATIONS:
The Chief of Police shall take the oath of office as prescribed by statute.
When appointing or approving the Chief of Police, the following qualifications
shall apply:
   A.   Education And Training: Training from an approved college or university
with specialization in law enforcement and meet all requirements prescribed by
law for the position of police officer in the State of Illinois.
   B.   Experience: Prior experience or any equivalent combination of training
is preferred, with administrative qualifications in respect to controlling and
supervising operations, personnel and the functions of a Municipal Police
Department. (Ord. 2009-15, 2-17-2009)
   C.   Residency: Shall reside within twenty five (25) miles of the Village
corporate limits unless otherwise specified by an agreement with the Board of
Trustees. (Ord. 2017-46, 5-18-2017)
1-8E-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Chief of Police, subject to general supervision by the Mayor, shall be
responsible for the direction of all activities of the Village Police
Department and other duties set forth herein which shall include, but are not
limited to, the following:
   A.   Supervisor: Discharge all day to day supervisory duties relating to the
Village Police Department including, but not limited to, the scheduling and
supervision of police officers, establish and set forth the general policies of
the Village Police Department, and supervise the operation and maintenance of
equipment and property of the Village Police Department.
   B.   Implement Duties: Implement those lawful duties as are directed by the
Mayor or by resolution of the Board of Trustees.
   C.   Enforcement: Enforce and execute all the applicable laws and statutes
of the Village and the State of Illinois.
   D.   Monthly Report: Provide a monthly report to the Board of Trustees of
activities in the Village relating to the Village Police Department. (Ord.
2009-15, 2-17-2009)
ARTICLE F. VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR
SECTION:
1-8F-1: Purpose; Office Established
1-8F-2: Appointment; Qualifications; Elected Officials Prohibited From Position
1-8F-3: Term Of Office
1-8F-4: Removal From Office
1-8F-5: Bond And Oath; Residency
1-8F-6: Employment Policies
1-8F-7: Powers And Duties
1-8F-1: PURPOSE; OFFICE ESTABLISHED:
The Board of Trustees hereby determines that the Office of Village
Administrator is necessary to carry into effect the powers conferred upon the
Village and hereby establishes said office as is provided by the Illinois
Municipal Code and the ordinances of the Village pertaining to said office.
(Ord. 2017-20, 4-20-2017)
1-8F-2: APPOINTMENT; QUALIFICATIONS; ELECTED OFFICIALS PROHIBITED FROM
POSITION:
The Village Administrator shall be appointed by the Mayor, with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees. The appointment and approval of the Village
Administrator shall be based upon executive and administrative qualifications
and reference to actual experience in or knowledge of accepted practices in the
administration and operation of municipal government in Illinois. No elected
official of the Village, including, but not limited to, the Mayor or any
Village Trustee, shall be appointed to the position of Village Administrator
during his term of office or for a period of one year after the expiration of
his respective term of office. (Ord. 2017-20, 4-20-2017)
1-8F-3: TERM OF OFFICE:
The term of the Village Administrator shall become effective commencing at the
first regularly scheduled meeting following the general Municipal election for
Mayor in the Village and shall be effective through and including the date of
expiration of the term of the Mayor unless discharged by the Mayor or by
resolution of the Board of Trustees prior to that date. (Ord. 2017-20, 4-20-
2017)
1-8F-4: REMOVAL FROM OFFICE:
The Village Administrator may be removed by the Mayor when it is the opinion of
the Mayor that such removal is in the best interest of the Village or as
provided under the Illinois Municipal Code. The Mayor shall report, in writing,
the reasons for the removal to the Board of Trustees at a meeting that shall be
held not less than five (5) nor more than ten (10) days after the removal from
said office. If the Mayor either fails to provide a written report of the
reasons for removal to the Board of Trustees or if the Board of Trustees, by a
two-thirds (2/3) majority vote, rejects the removal, the Village Administrator
shall be restored to office. A new bond and oath must be provided by the
Village Administrator after restoration. (Ord. 2017-20, 4-20-2017)
1-8F-5: BOND AND OATH; RESIDENCY:
Before entering upon the duties of office, the Village Administrator shall
execute a bond in such amount as fixed by resolution, with sureties approved by
the Mayor and Board of Trustees, and conditioned upon the faithful performance
of the duties of the Office of Village Administrator. In addition thereto, the
appointee shall execute any necessary oath or other affirmation required by
such office and shall, as a part of qualification for said office, and shall
reside within twenty five (25) miles of the Village corporate limits unless
otherwise agreed by the Village Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2017-36, 5-18-2017)
1-8F-6: EMPLOYMENT POLICIES:
The position of Village Administrator, as provided herein, shall be subject to
the following employment policies, subject to amendment from time to time by
the Board of Trustees. The Village Administrator shall:
   A.   At the time of appointment, have all relevant details of employment
stated in the resolution of consent for appointment by the Board of Trustees
that are not specifically provided in this chapter, in the employee handbook,
or any policies and practices heretofore or hereinafter adopted by the Board of
Trustees;
   B.   Be paid a salary which shall be determined by the Board of Trustees as
outlined in the annual budget and shall not be increased or decreased within
the fiscal year;
   C.   During the term of office with the Village, accept no other employment
without the express permission of the Mayor and Board of Trustees, and dedicate
such time and effort as may be necessary to discharge all of the duties and
responsibilities of the position;
   D.   Devote not less than forty (40) hours per calendar week to such
employment and be available and accessible for receiving emergency calls after
normal business hours from the Mayor, members of the Board of Trustees, Chief
of Police and heads of other departments of the Village to provide assistance,
services, supervision and information regarding urgent circumstances which may
arise during such period;
   E.   Unless a vehicle is provided to the Village Administrator by the
Village, be reimbursed for personal vehicle use in the discharge of duties as
the Village Administrator at the maximum allowable rate as from time to time
determined and published by the Internal Revenue Service of the United States
Treasury for reimbursement of personal vehicle use in a business or profession
1 ;
   F.   Attend such continuing education, professional development and related
educational conferences, seminars and programs for certification as a Village
Administrator which are directly related to the discharge of the duties of
Village Administrator and be reimbursed by the Village at an amount not to
exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per fiscal year or such amount provided
in the Village budget, whichever is less;
   G.   Receive disability, health, dental and life insurance benefits as
provided to all other full time employees of the Village; and
   H.   Be credited for such vacation, sick and personal time as is provided to
all other full time employees of the Village, and as such may be amended from
time to time by the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2017-20, 4-20-2017)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection 1-7-1C of this title.
1-8F-7: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Village Administrator shall perform all duties in the appropriate and
efficient administration of the government of the Village. Such duties, as
provided in this section, may be supplemented, modified or amended by amendment
of this article, or such other necessary enactments or adoptions by the Mayor
and the Board of Trustees from time to time. In connection therewith, the
Village Administrator shall:
   A.   General Duties:
      1.   Exercise administrative, managerial and supervisory control of all
Village departments, employees, functions and operations.
      2.   Under general direction of the Mayor, supervise operations of the
Village departments and officials, including, but not limited to, the Director
of Public Works (and the streets and alleys, water and sewer treatment and
collection system), the Chief of Police, and all other Municipal employees and
officers; and consult with the Village Clerk, Village Treasurer, Village
Engineer and Village Attorney.
      3.   Recommend to the Mayor and Board of Trustees such measures which are
in the best interest of the Village.
      4.   Implement and carry out the policy direction and procedures
established by the Mayor or by resolution of the Board of Trustees.
      5.   Assist the Mayor and advise the Board of Trustees in the appointment
and removal process of appointed officials or officers of the Village which, by
statute or ordinance, are to be appointed or removed by them.
      6.   Assist in the planning and supervision of the Village streets and
alleys and sewer and water functions.
      7.   Serve as the Village Zoning and/or Building Enforcement Officer, if
deemed qualified, with the duties and responsibilities of those officers or as
prescribed by ordinance 1 .
      8.   Attend meetings of the Board of Trustees, standing committees of the
Village, and other various Village boards and commissions, if needed, with
authority to participate and assist in the discussions, but without the right
to vote.
      9.   Prepare status reports to the Mayor and Board of Trustees of all
departments and other topics pertinent to the efficient operation of the
Village.
      10.   Prepare other written documents and reports at the direction of the
Mayor, the Board of Trustees and other boards and commissions; and provide
written evaluation and progress reports to the Board of Trustees no less
frequently than monthly on the operations of the various Village departments if
requested.
      11.   Carry out the duties and responsibilities of Budget Officer of the
Village 2  which includes, but is not limited to, approving and executing
documents for purchases that do not require prior Village Board action and
preparing bid specifications with the concurrence of appropriate Village
supervisory personnel unless a Budget Officer is otherwise appointed by the
Mayor and Village Board.
      12.   Assist in developing and maintaining intergovernmental
relationships with units of local government and other agencies, departments
and governmental units having relations with or jurisdiction over the Village.
      13.   Investigate all complaints in relation to matters concerning the
administration of the government of the Village and services maintained by the
public utilities in the Village.
      14.   Keep current inventory of all real and personal property of the
Village and the location of such property, except property that is assigned to
some other officer or body for care and control.
      15.   Perform other duties as may be required by the Board of Trustees
consistent with law and ordinances of the Village.
   B.   Personnel Duties:
      1.   Manage all personnel functions and ensure compliance with all
applicable Federal and State employment and labor laws and regulations.
      2.   Recruit, screen and evaluate all candidates for employment with the
Village, and submit recommended candidates to the Mayor for appointment, with
the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. The recruitment, screening and
evaluation process shall conform to the policies and procedures of the Village.
      3.   After consultation with the Mayor and committee Chairs, recommend
appointment or removal of any other Municipal supervisory employee to the Board
of Trustees for confirmation.
      4.   After consultation with the Municipal supervisory employee involved,
recommend appointment or removal of all subordinate Village employees, workers
and laborers to the Board of Trustees for confirmation.
      5.   Develop work schedule plans for the Village work force and supervise
implementation of those work schedule plans by the Village's supervisory staff.
      6.   Prepare all department supervisor employee performance reviews and
review all other performance evaluations for presentation to the Board of
Trustees for review.
      7.   Make recommendations to the Mayor and the Board of Trustees in
regard to wage/benefit modifications.
      8.   Administer Village personnel procedures and policies and recommend
changes of such to the Board of Trustees when deemed appropriate.
      9.   Subject to statutory limitations, maintain all active personnel
files, forms and records. (Ord. 2017-20, 4-20-2017)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection 11-5-1A of this Code for Zoning Administrator.
2 2. See article J of this chapter.
ARTICLE G. VILLAGE ATTORNEY
SECTION:
1-8G-1: Appointment, Term And Compensation
1-8G-2: Duties
1-8G-3: Qualifications
1-8G-1: APPOINTMENT, TERM AND COMPENSATION:
The Village Attorney(s) may be appointed by the Mayor, with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees, or be a contracted employee position of the
Village. If appointed, the appointment shall become effective commencing at the
first regularly scheduled meeting following the general Municipal election for
Mayor in the Village and shall be effective through and including the date of
expiration of the term of Mayor unless said attorney(s) is discharged by the
Mayor or by resolution of the Board of Trustees prior to that date.
Compensation shall be determined by the Board of Trustees as outlined in the
annual budget or as specified in any contract adopted by the Board for said
position. (Ord. 2010-23, 6-21-2010; amd. 2011 Code)
1-8G-2: DUTIES:
The duties of the Village Attorney(s) shall include, but are not limited to,
the discharge of any and all duties as provided by the Illinois Municipal Code
and the ordinances of the Village pertaining to said office, and the
performance of such other duties as are directed by the Mayor, committees and
the Board of Trustees, and any other duties which, in the appropriate discharge
of the professional judgment of the Village Attorney(s), are necessary and
legally appropriate for the proper conduct of the legal affairs of the Village.
(Ord. 2009-16, 2-17-2009)
1-8G-3: QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   Residency: Shall reside within twenty five (25) miles of the Village
corporate limits unless otherwise specifically approved by the Board of
Trustees. (Ord. 2017-34, 5-18-2017)
ARTICLE H. VILLAGE ENGINEER
SECTION:
1-8H-1: Appointment, Term And Compensation
1-8H-2: Qualifications
1-8H-3: Powers And Duties
1-8H-1: APPOINTMENT, TERM AND COMPENSATION:
The Village Engineer(s) shall be appointed by the Mayor with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees. The appointment shall become effective
commencing at the first regularly scheduled meeting following the general
Municipal election for Mayor in the Village, or as soon thereafter as may be
practicable, and shall be effective through and including the date of
expiration of the term of Mayor unless said engineer(s) is removed by the
Mayor, the position is discontinued by resolution of the Board of Trustees per
State Statute prior to that date, and/or a new engineer is appointed and
qualifies. Compensation shall be determined by the Board of Trustees as
outlined in the annual Appropriation or Salary Ordinance. (Ord. 2014-15, 6-5-
2014)
1-8H-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   The Village Engineer, if appointment is for an in-house engineer, must
have the following qualifications:
      1.   Education And Experience:
         a.   A degree in civil engineering;
         b.   Valid civil engineering license or equivalent;
         c.   Preference of at least five (5) years of progressively
responsible experience in the field as civil engineer;
         d.   Preference of a surveyor's license;
         e.   Considerable experience in utilities, public works, land
development regulations and capital projects management;
         f.   Thorough knowledge of practices and principles of professional
civil engineering;
         g.   Thorough knowledge and ability to apply the laws and requirements
related to the engineering function with an Illinois municipality;
         h.   Demonstrated Municipal professional engineering experience at
progressively responsible levels, including project management and personnel
supervision;
         i.   Demonstrated ability to plan, schedule and complete multiple
projects and objectives;
         j.   Considerable analytical skills; ability to solve problems,
exercise sound judgment and initiative; ability to work independently;
         k.   Ability to establish and maintain effective working relationship
with other employees, developers, agencies, public officials and the general
public;
         l.   Ability to effectively meet with citizens and handle customer
complaints; and
         m.   Ability to communicate effectively both orally and in writing;
ability to make public presentations.
      2.   Mandatory Physical Requirements: The engineer must be able to:
         a.   Endurance/Moving About: Frequently physically move from location
to location for extended periods.
         b.   Endurance/Overall Strength: Intermediate work. Exert force and/or
lift or carry objects weighing up to forty (40) pounds periodically.
         c.   Walking: Frequently walk and move about on foot for extended
periods.
         d.   Sitting: Frequently be able to sit for extended periods.
         e.   Pushing/Pulling: Periodic. Push by exerting force on an object so
that it moves away from the force or worker (including, but not limited to,
slapping, striking, kicking, and treadle actions); and/or pull by exerting
force on an object so that it moves toward the force or worker (including
jerking).
         f.   Controls: Frequently. Use one or both arms and/or hands; use one
or either feet or legs to move controls on machinery or equipment.
         g.   Climbing: Periodic. Ascend or descend ladders, stairs,
scaffolding, ramps, poles, ropes, exit ditches or holes and the like using the
feet and legs and/or hands and arms.
         h.   Balancing: Periodic. Maintain body equilibrium to prevent falling
when walking, standing, crouching, or running on narrow, slippery or
erratically moving surfaces.
         i.   Bending/Stooping: Periodic. Stoop by bending the body downward or
forward by flexing the spine at the waist, and/or bend by extending the spine
backward or from side to side.
         j.   Kneeling/Crouching: Periodic. Kneel by bending the legs at the
knees to come to rest on the knee or knees, and/or crouch by bending the body
downward and forward by bending the legs and spine.
         k.   Crawling: Periodic. Move about on the hands and knees or hands
and feet.
         l.   Reaching: Constantly. Extend hands and arms in any direction.
         m.   Handling: Constantly. Seize, hold, grasp, turn or otherwise work
with the hand or hands.
         n.   Rotation: Frequently. Twist and turn the spine or a ball and
socket joint such as the shoulder or hip.
         o.   Talking: Constantly. Express or exchange ideas by means of the
spoken word to impart oral information to Village employees or officials or to
the public and convey detailed spoken instructions to other workers accurately,
loudly or quickly.
         p.   Hearing: Constantly. Perceive the nature of sounds by the ear.
         q.   Seeing: Constantly. Perceive the nature of sights by the eyes.
         r.   Reading: Read water meters, written reports, and instructions as
well as schematic and engineering plans.
         s.   Writing: Ability to accurately record water meter readings,
record information and summary of events.
         t.   Miscellaneous: Such other reasonable physical and mental
abilities that may be required to carry out the position. (Ord. 2014-15, 6-5-
2014)
      3.   Residency: Residency within the Village corporate limits is not
required; however, the engineer shall reside at all times within twenty five
(25) miles of the corporate limits of the Village unless otherwise agreed by
way of action by the Village Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2017-35, 5-18-2017)
1-8H-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The following are the general powers and duties of the Village
Engineer:
      1.   Plan, coordinate and process engineering reviews including, but not
limited to, proposed plats, site plans, water and wastewater systems, paving,
drainage, construction and landscape improvements;
      2.   Prepare engineering design plans and specifications for projects to
be completed by staff and/or contractors;
      3.   Oversee and insure conformance with designs, project requirements,
this Code, and established engineering practices for various projects completed
by staff or contractors;
      4.   Manage contracts for capital improvement projects; oversee
construction; coordinate and complete bid processes and documents;
      5.   Assist with obtaining grants, grant underwriting, and grant
administration and oversight;
      6.   Develop and revise standard design and construction specifications
for Village road, utility, drainage and irrigation systems;
      7.   Prepares and delivers reports related to assigned projects and
services;
      8.   Investigates complaints and requests for services; meets with
employees and the general public;
      9.   Coordinates activities with other departments; acts as a liaison
with other governmental agencies and developers;
      10.   Manage use of Village right-of-ways;
      11.   Attends meetings and conferences, including board and committee
meetings;
      12.   Any such other duties and responsibilities as provided by the
Illinois Municipal Code and the ordinances of the Village pertaining to said
office and/or that may be necessary and appropriate for the position or for the
proper conduct and operation of the affairs of the Village.
   B.   The following are additional general powers and duties, in addition to
powers and duties hereinbefore listed, for an in- house engineer:
      1.   Assist with, conduct and/or review departmental performance
evaluations in conjunction with the Director of Public Works or such other
appropriate department supervisor(s);
      2.   Prepare and/or assist with budget preparation and implementation and
work schedules, if necessary, for the Public Works Department;
      3.   Work with Village Code Compliance Officers and/or act as a Village
Code Compliance Officer when appointed to that position;
      4.   Maintain and promulgate standard operating procedures in accordance
with Village policies and procedures;
      5.   Provides general supervision and technical assistance in the Public
Works Department in conjunction with other department supervisors; and
      6.   Administer Village personnel procedures and policies and recommend
changes of such to the administration and Board of Trustees when deemed
appropriate. (Ord. 2014-15, 6-5-2014)
ARTICLE I. SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS
SECTION:
1-8I-1: Appointment, Term And Compensation
1-8I-2: Oath And Bond
1-8I-3: Qualifications
1-8I-4: Employment Policies
1-8I-5: Powers And Duties
1-8I-1: APPOINTMENT, TERM AND COMPENSATION:
The Superintendent of Public Works shall be appointed by the Mayor with the
advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. The appointment shall become
effective commencing at the first regularly scheduled meeting following the
general Municipal election for Mayor or as soon thereafter as is practicable in
the Village and shall be effective through and including the date of expiration
of the term of Mayor unless said Superintendent is removed by the Mayor or by
resolution of the Board of Trustees per State Statute prior to that date.
Compensation shall be determined by the Board of Trustees as outlined in the
annual Appropriation Ordinance. (Ord. 2013-38, 9-19-2013)
1-8I-2: OATH AND BOND:
Due to the confidential nature of this office, the Superintendent of Public
Works shall, before entering upon the duties of office, execute a bond with
sureties in such amount to be fixed by resolution and approved by the Board of
Trustees, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the Superintendent of
Public Works' duties. The Superintendent of Public Works shall take the oath of
office prescribed by statute. (Ord. 2013-38, 9-19-2013)
1-8I-3: QUALIFICATIONS:
The Superintendent of Public Works must have the following qualifications:
   A.   Mandatory General Requirements: The Superintendent of Public Works
must:
      1.   Experience: Have prior experience or any equivalent combination of
training is preferred, with administrative qualifications in respect to
controlling and supervising operations, personnel, budgets and the functions of
a Municipal Public Works Department.
      2.   Licensing: Have, either prior to or at the time of appointment of
office, appropriate licensing for the operation of the water and sewerage
system of the Village.
      3.   Satisfactory Performance: Be able to perform each duty hereinafter
stated satisfactorily.
      4.   Communication Skills: Have good communication skills and a calm
demeanor in responding to citizen questions and complaints and in dealing with
the general public in everyday activities as well as employees, other
supervisors, and the Village administration and Board. (Ord. 2013-38, 9-19-
2013)
      5.   Follow Directives: Follow the lawful directives issued by the Mayor,
Village Administrator, and other appropriate supervisors or officials of the
Village. (Ord. 2013-38, 9-19-2013; amd. Ord. 2017-20, 4-20-2017)
      6.   Work Within Guidelines: Have the ability to work within established
guidelines.
      7.   Perform Repetitious Tasks: Have the ability to perform repetitious
tasks.
      8.   Use Of Machinery: Have the ability to use and operate pick-up
trucks; tractors; forklifts; lawnmowers; weedeaters; chain saws; chippers;
blowers; various spray equipment; and miscellaneous power tools for turf
maintenance, carpentry, painting, plumbing, and cement finishing work.
   B.   Mandatory Physical Requirements: The Superintendent of Public Works
must be able to:
      1.   Endurance/Moving About: Frequently physically move from location to
location for extended periods.
      2.   Endurance/Overall Strength: Heavy work. Exert force and/or lift or
carry objects weighing up to fifty (50) pounds regularly.
      3.   Walking: Constantly walk and move about on foot for extended
periods.
      4.   Sitting: Frequently be able to sit for extended periods.
      5.   Lifting/Carrying: Periodic. Lift by manually raising or lowering an
object from one level to another (including upward pulling), and/or carry or
transport objects, usually holding items in the hands or arms or on the
shoulder.
      6.   Pushing/Pulling: Periodic. Push by exerting force on an object so
that it moves away from the force or worker (including, but not limited to,
slapping, striking, kicking, and treadle actions); and/or pull by exerting
force on an object so that it moves toward the force or worker (including
jerking).
      7.   Controls: Frequently. Use one or both arms and/or hands; use one or
either feet or legs to move controls on machinery or equipment.
      8.   Climbing: Periodic. Ascend or descend ladders, stairs, scaffolding,
ramps, poles, ropes, and the like using the feet and legs and/or hands and
arms.
      9.   Balancing: Periodic. Maintain body equilibrium to prevent falling
when walking, standing, crouching, or running on narrow, slippery or
erratically moving surfaces.
      10.   Bending/Stooping: Periodic. Stoop by bending the body downward or
forward by flexing the spine at the waist, and/or bend by extending the spine
backward or from side to side.
      11.   Kneeling/Crouching: Periodic. Kneel by bending the legs at the
knees to come to rest on the knee or knees, and/or crouch by bending the body
downward and forward by bending the legs and spine.
      12.   Crawling: Periodic. Move about on the hands and knees or hands and
feet.
      13.   Reaching: Constantly. Extend hands and arms in any direction.
      14.   Handling: Constantly. Seize, hold, grasp, turn or otherwise work
with the hand or hands.
      15.   Rotation: Frequently. Twist and turn the spine or a ball and socket
joint such as the shoulder or hip.
      16.   Talking: Constantly. Express or exchange ideas by means of the
spoken word to impart oral information to Village employees or officials or to
the public and convey detailed spoken instructions to other workers accurately,
loudly or quickly.
      17.   Hearing: Constantly. Perceive the nature of sounds by the ear.
      18.   Seeing: Constantly. Perceive the nature of sights by the eyes.
      19.   Reading: Read water meters, written reports, and instructions.
      20.   Writing: Ability to accurately record water meter readings, record
information and summary of events.
      21.   Miscellaneous: Such other reasonable physical and mental abilities
that may be required to carry out the position.
   C.   Residency: Shall reside within the Village corporate limits unless
otherwise specified by an agreement with the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2013-38,
9-19-2013)
1-8I-4: EMPLOYMENT POLICIES:
The position of Superintendent of Public Works shall be subject to the
following employment policies, subject to amendment from time to time by the
Board of Trustees. The Superintendent of Public Works shall:
   A.   At the time of appointment, have all relevant details of employment
stated in the resolution of consent for appointment by the Board of Trustees
that are not specifically provided for in this chapter, in the employee
handbook, or any policies and practices heretofore or hereinafter adopted by
the Board of Trustees;
   B.   During the term of office with the Village, accept no other employment
without the express permission of the Mayor and Board of Trustees, and shall
dedicate such time and effort as may be necessary to discharge all of the
duties and responsibilities of the position; (Ord. 2013-38, 9-19-2013)
   C.   Devote not less than forty (40) hours per calendar week to such
employment and shall be available and accessible for receiving emergency calls
after normal business hours from the Mayor, Village Administrator or such other
appropriate supervisor, members of the Board of Trustees, Chief of Police and
heads of other departments of the Village to provide assistance, services,
supervision and information regarding urgent circumstances which may arise
during such period; (Ord. 2013-38, 9-19-2013; amd. Ord. 2017-20, 4-20-2017)
   D.   Attend such continuing education, professional development and related
educational conferences, seminars and programs for certification to the
discharge of the duties of the Superintendent of Public Works and shall be
reimbursed by the Village at an amount not to exceed one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) per fiscal year or such amount provided for in the Village budget,
whichever is less;
   E.   Receive such disability, health, dental and life insurance benefits as
may be provided to all other full time employees of the Village; and
   F.   Be credited for such vacation, sick and personal time as is provided to
all other full time employees of the Village, and as such may be amended from
time to time by the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2013-38, 9-19-2013)
1-8I-5: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Superintendent of Public Works shall perform all duties necessary for the
appropriate and efficient operation of the public works of the Village,
including, but not limited to, the Village parks, streets, alleys, right-of-
ways, culverts, drainage, sewerage and water infrastructures. Such duties
provided for in this section may be supplemented, modified or amended by
amendment of this chapter, or such other necessary enactments or adoptions by
the Mayor and the Board of Trustees from time to time. In connection therewith,
the Superintendent of Public Works shall: (Ord. 2013-38, 9-19-2013)
   A.   General Duties:
      1.   Be responsible for the direct supervision, subject to the general
supervision of the Mayor and the Village Administrator or such other
appropriate supervisor, of all public works employees; (Ord. 2013-38, 9-19-
2013; amd. Ord. 2017-20, 4-20-2017)
      2.   Oversee the activities and projects necessary to maintain the day-
to-day public works functions and operations;
      3.   Oversee that all duties of the public works employees are
appropriately performed and administered;
      4.   Act as the general safety advisor and safety enforcement official
for the Public Works Department and take such reasonable measures that all
necessary safety equipment is provided and utilized;
      5.   Recommend to the Mayor and Board of Trustees such measures deemed in
the best interest of the Village Public Works Departments and operations; (Ord.
2013-38, 9-19-2013)
      6.   Implement and carry out the direction and procedures established by
the Mayor, Village Administrator or such other similar supervisor, or by
ordinance or resolution of the Board of Trustees; (Ord. 2013-38, 9-19-2013;
amd. Ord. 2017-20, 4-20-2017)
      7.   Assist in the planning, supervision, and maintenance of the Village
streets and alleys, parks, drainage, sidewalks and sewer and water functions;
      8.   When requested, attend the meetings of the Board of Trustees,
standing committees of the Village, and other various Village boards and
commissions, with authority to participate and assist in the discussions, but
without right to vote;
      9.   Prepare a biweekly typed status report of the status of the Public
Works Departments and other topics pertinent to the efficient operation of the
Village Public Works to the Mayor and Board of Trustees and include in such
report the public works' activities over the past month, monthly vehicle
maintenance reports for each Public Works vehicle, and such other items that
may be requested by the Village administration or Board;
      10.   Keep current inventory of all real and personal property of the
Village Public Works Departments and provide such information upon request by
the Village administration or Board;
      11.   Adequately maintain all public works' vehicles and equipment and
keep appropriate records of such maintenance;
      12.   Prepare a recommended general budget and operating budget for the
Public Works Departments and provide such reports to the Budget Officer of the
Village, the Village administration, and the Village Board;
      13.   Administer and periodical review any formal budgets adopted by the
Village Board for the Public Works Department and provide recommendation to the
Village Board of any issues thereto related; and
      14.   Perform other duties as may be required by the Board of Trustees or
administration consistent with law and ordinances of the Village.
   B.   Personnel Duties:
      1.   Manage public works personnel functions and ensure compliance with
all applicable Federal and State employment and labor laws and regulations;
      2.   Recruit, screen and evaluate all candidates for employment with the
Village Public Works Departments;
      3.   Develop work schedule plans for the public works employees, and
supervise implementation of those work schedule plans;
      4.   Prepare all public works employee performance reviews for
presentation to the Board of Trustees for review and approval;
      5.   Create and administer such policies, subject to approval by the
Village administration and Board, as may be necessary and appropriate for the
safe operation of the Public Works Department and its employees; and
      6.   Administer Village personnel procedures and policies and recommend
changes of such to the Board of Trustees when appropriate. (Ord. 2013-38, 9-19-
2013)
ARTICLE J. BUDGET OFFICER
SECTION:
1-8J-1: Creation Of Office
1-8J-2: Appointment, Term And Compensation
1-8J-3: Bond And Oath
1-8J-4: Qualifications
1-8J-5: Powers And Duties
1-8J-1: CREATION OF OFFICE:
There is hereby created the Budget Officer of the Village. The Village
Administrator or other designee of the Mayor is hereby designated as the Budget
Officer of the Village. (Ord. 2009-74, 5-18-2009; amd. Ord. 2017-20, 4-20-2017)
1-8J-2: APPOINTMENT, TERM AND COMPENSATION:
The Budget Officer shall be appointed by the Mayor, with the advice and consent
of the Board of Trustees. The appointment shall become effective commencing at
the first regularly scheduled meeting following the general Municipal election
for Mayor in the Village and shall be effective through and including the date
of expiration of the term of Mayor unless said Budget Officer is removed by the
Mayor or by resolution of the Board of Trustees, per State Statute, prior to
that date. Compensation shall be determined by the Board of Trustees as
outlined in the annual budget. (Ord. 2009-74, 5-18-2009; amd. 2011 Code)
1-8J-3: BOND AND OATH:
Before entering upon the duties of office, the Budget Officer shall execute a
bond with sureties in such amount to be fixed by resolution and to be approved
by the Board of Trustees, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the
Budget Officer's duties as set forth herein or by statute, and conditioned upon
the indemnification of the Village for any loss by reason of any neglect of
duty or any requirement of the Budget Officer. The Budget Officer shall take
the oath of office as prescribed by statute 1 . (Ord. 2009-74, 5-18-2009)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25.
1-8J-4: QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   Residency: The Budget Officer shall reside within twenty five (25)
miles of the Village corporate limits unless otherwise specifically approved by
the Village Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2017-39, 5-18-2017)
1-8J-5: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Budget Officer shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   Permit, encourage and establish the use of efficient planning,
budgeting, auditing, reporting, accounting, and other fiscal management
procedures in all Village departments, commissions, and boards;
   B.   Compile an annual budget in accordance with section 8-2-9.3 of the
Illinois Municipal Code 1 ;
   C.   Examine all books and records of all Village departments, commissions
and boards which relate to monies received by the Village and Village
departments, commissions and boards and paid out by the Village and Village
departments, commissions, and boards, debts and accounts receivable, and
amounts owed by or to the Village and Village departments, commissions, and
boards;
   D.   Obtain such additional information from the Village and Village
departments, commissions and boards as may be useful to the Budget Officer for
purposes of compiling a Village budget; such information to be furnished by the
Village and Village departments, commissions, and boards in the form required
by the Budget Officer. Any department, commission or board which refuses to
make such information as is requested thereof available to the Budget Officer
shall not be permitted to make expenditures under any subsequent budget for the
Village until such Village department, commission or board shall comply in full
with the request of the Budget Officer;
   E.   Establish and maintain such procedures as shall ensure that no
expenditures are made by the Village or Village departments, commissions, or
boards except as authorized by the budget; and
   F.   Perform such other tasks or duties assigned to the Budget Officer by
the Mayor or Mayor's designee. (Ord. 2017-39, 5-18-2017)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/8-2-9.3.
ARTICLE K. FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT OFFICER
SECTION:
1-8K-1: Created; Appointment
1-8K-2: Bond And Oath
1-8K-3: Duties
1-8K-4: FOIA Requests And Responses
1-8K-1: CREATED; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the office of freedom of information act (FOIA)
officer. The FOIA officer(s) shall be appointed by the mayor, with the advice
and consent of the board of trustees, on the first regularly scheduled board
meeting in May following a general election 1 . (Ord. 2009-132, 12-7-2009)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 140/3.5.
1-8K-2: BOND AND OATH:
Due to the confidential nature of this office, the FOIA officer shall, before
entering upon the duties of office, execute a bond with sureties in such amount
to be fixed by resolution and approved by the board of trustees, conditioned
upon the faithful performance of the FOIA officer's duties. FOIA officers shall
take the same oath of office prescribed by statute for the village clerk. (Ord.
2009-132, 12-7-2009)
1-8K-3: DUTIES:
The duties of the FOIA officer(s) shall include, but are not limited to, the
following:
   A.   Within thirty (30) days of being appointed, must undergo and
successfully complete an electronic training curriculum developed by the public
access counselor for FOIA officers.
   B.   Annually complete the electronic training curriculum thereinafter 1 .
   C.   When requested, attend the meetings of the board of trustees, standing
committees of the village, and other various village boards and commissions,
with authority to participate and assist in the discussions, but without the
right to vote.
   D.   Maintain a list of documents or categories of documents that will be
immediately disclosed upon request 2 .
   E.   Create and maintain a file for retention of the original FOIA request,
a copy of the response, and a record of all written communications with the
requester and copies thereof to be kept at the office of the village clerk.
   F.   Cause to be posted a prominent display at each public office of the
village, and make available to the public, a brief description of the village
which shall include, but not be limited to:
      1.   A short summary of its purpose.
      2.   A block diagram giving its functional subdivisions.
      3.   The total amount of its operating budget.
      4.   The number and location of its offices.
      5.   The approximate number of full time and part time employees.
      6.   The identification and membership of any board, commission,
committee, or council which operates in an advisory capacity, or which
exercises control, or which the board of trustees is required to report 3 .
      7.   A brief description of methods of how the public may request
information and records, a directory of designated FOIA officer(s), the address
where requests are to be directed, and any applicable fees for FOIA requests 4
.
      8.   Post the display on the village website, if operational.
   G.   Perform other duties as may be required by the board of trustees
consistent with law and ordinances of the village. (Ord. 2009-132, 12-7-2009)
 
Notes
1 2. 5 ILCS 140/3.5(b).
2 1. 5 ILCS 140/3.5.
3 2. 5 ILCS 140/4(a).
4 3. 5 ILCS 140/4(b).
1-8K-4: FOIA REQUESTS AND RESPONSES:
   A.   FOIA requests shall, at a minimum, be:
      1.   Submitted on a form authorized by the village;
      2.   Submitted to the office of the village clerk; and
      3.   Signed by the person making the request.
   B.   Each response to an FOIA request shall include, at a minimum, the
following:
      1.   The date the village received the request.
      2.   Compute the day on which the time to respond falls and note that
date on the request.
      3.   Maintain an electronic or paper copy of the request and all
documents submitted with it, until complied with or denied.
      4.   The basis or section that authorizes denial, if denied.
      5.   The names and titles or positions of each person responsible for the
denial.
      6.   The fees incurred for the request, if applicable.
      7.   If denied, informing the person of his right to appeal to the mayor
or the right to judicial review if the mayor assisted in the decision to deny
the request.
      8.   Any other item required pursuant to the Illinois freedom of
information act 1 .
   C.   FOIA officers may request clarification from the requesting party of
what information or items are being requested. (Ord. 2009-132, 12-7-2009)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.
ARTICLE L. DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS
SECTION:
1-8L-1: Appointment, Term And Compensation
1-8L-2: Qualifications
1-8L-3: Employment Policies
1-8L-4: Powers And Duties
1-8L-1: APPOINTMENT, TERM AND COMPENSATION:
The Director of Public Works shall be appointed by the Mayor with the advice
and consent of the Board of Trustees. The appointment shall become effective
commencing at the first regularly scheduled meeting following the general
Municipal election for Mayor in the Village, or as soon thereafter as
practicable, and shall be effective through and including the date of
expiration of the term of Mayor unless said Director is removed by the Mayor,
the position is discontinued by resolution of the Board of Trustees per State
Statute prior to that date, and/or a new Director is appointed and qualifies.
Compensation shall be determined by the Board of Trustees as outlined in the
annual Appropriation or Salary Ordinance. (Ord. 2014-14, 6-5-2014)
1-8L-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   The Director of Public Works must have the following qualifications:
      1.   Education And Experience:
         a.   A higher education degree, specifically a civil engineering
degree, is preferred with an associate degree or trade degree relevant to the
position minimally being required;
         b.   Prior experience or any equivalent combination of training is
preferred, with administrative qualifications in respect to controlling and
supervising operations, personnel and the functions of a Municipal Public Works
Department;
         c.   Demonstrated ability to plan, schedule and complete multiple
projects and objectives;
         d.   Considerable analytical skills; ability to solve problems,
exercise sound judgment and initiative; ability to work independently;
         e.   Ability to establish and maintain effective working relationship
with other employees, developers, agencies, public officials and the general
public;
         f.   Ability to effectively meet with citizens and handle customer
complaints; and
         g.   Ability to communicate effectively both orally and in writing;
ability to make public presentations.
      2.   Licensing And Certifications: The Village operates a water treatment
plant and sewer treatment plant that requires licensing and certifications from
the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. As such, the Village prefers the
Director of Public Works to either have or obtain as soon as eligible the
appropriate licensing and certifications necessary to operate these facilities.
      3.   Mandatory Physical Requirements: The Director of Public Works must
be able to:
         a.   Endurance/Moving About: Frequently physically move from location
to location for extended periods.
         b.   Endurance/Overall Strength: Intermediate work. Exert force and/or
lift or carry objects weighing up to forty (40) pounds periodically.
         c.   Walking: Frequently walk and move about on foot for extended
periods.
         d.   Sitting: Frequently be able to sit for extended periods.
         e.   Pushing/Pulling: Periodic. Push by exerting force on an object so
that it moves away from the force or worker (including, but not limited to,
slapping, striking, kicking, and treadle actions); and/or pull by exerting
force on an object so that it moves toward the force or worker (including
jerking).
         f.   Controls: Frequently. Use one or both arms and/or hands; use one
or either feet or legs to move controls on machinery or equipment.
         g.   Climbing: Periodic. Ascend or descend ladders, stairs,
scaffolding, ramps, poles, ropes, exit ditches or holes and the like using the
feet and legs and/or hands and arms.
         h.   Balancing: Periodic. Maintain body equilibrium to prevent falling
when walking, standing, crouching, or running on narrow, slippery or
erratically moving surfaces.
         i.   Bending/Stooping: Periodic. Stoop by bending the body downward or
forward by flexing the spine at the waist, and/or bend by extending the spine
backward or from side to side.
         j.   Kneeling/Crouching: Periodic. Kneel by bending the legs at the
knees to come to rest on the knee or knees, and/or crouch by bending the body
downward and forward by bending the legs and spine.
         k.   Crawling: Periodic. Move about on the hands and knees or hands
and feet.
         l.   Reaching: Constantly. Extend hands and arms in any direction.
         m.   Handling: Constantly. Seize, hold, grasp, turn or otherwise work
with the hand or hands.
         n.   Rotation: Frequently. Twist and turn the spine or a ball and
socket joint such as the shoulder or hip.
         o.   Talking: Constantly. Express or exchange ideas by means of the
spoken word to impart oral information to Village employees or officials or to
the public and convey detailed spoken instructions to other workers accurately,
loudly or quickly.
         p.   Hearing: Constantly. Perceive the nature of sounds by the ear.
         q.   Seeing: Constantly. Perceive the nature of sights by the eyes.
         r.   Reading: Read water meters, written reports, and instructions.
         s.   Writing: Ability to accurately record water meter readings,
record information and summary of events.
         t.   Miscellaneous: Such other reasonable physical and mental
abilities that may be required to carry out the position. (Ord. 2014-14, 6-5-
2014)
      4.   Residency: Residency within the Village corporate limits is not
required; however, the Director of Public Works shall reside at all times
within twenty five (25) miles of the corporate limits of the Village unless
otherwise agreed by way of action by the Village Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2017-
32, 5-18-2017)
1-8L-3: EMPLOYMENT POLICIES:
   A.   The position of Director of Public Works shall be subject to the
following employment policies, subject to amendment from time to time by the
Board of Trustees. The Director of Public Works shall:
      1.   At the time of appointment, have all relevant details of employment
stated in the resolution of consent for appointment by the Board of Trustees
that are not specifically provided for in this chapter, in the employee
handbook, or any policies and practices heretofore or hereinafter adopted by
the Board of Trustees; however, such relevant details shall not be construed
nor is it intended to establish an employment contract;
      2.   During the term of office with the Village, accept no other
employment without the express permission of the Mayor and Board of Trustees,
and shall dedicate such time and effort as may be necessary to discharge all of
the duties and responsibilities of the position; and
      3.   Devote not less than forty (40) hours per calendar week to such
employment and shall be available and accessible for receiving emergency calls
after normal business hours from the Mayor, members of the Board of Trustees,
Chief of Police and heads of other departments of the Village to provide
assistance, services, supervision and information regarding urgent
circumstances which may arise during such period. (Ord. 2014-14, 6-5-2014)
1-8L-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The Director of Public Works, working with the Village Administrator,
Village Engineer, and heads of Public Works, shall perform all duties necessary
for the appropriate and efficient operation of the Public Works of the Village,
including, but not limited to the streets, alleys, sidewalks, right-of-ways,
parks, culverts, storm sewer, sewerage and water infrastructures. Such duties
provided for in this section may be supplemented, modified or amended by
amendment of this chapter, or such other necessary enactments or adoptions by
the Board of Trustees from time to time. In connection therewith, the Director
of Public Works shall: (Ord. 2014-14, 6-5-2014; amd. Ord. 2017-20, 4-20-2017)
      1.   General Duties:
         a.   Have charge over the maintenance and general operation of: the
Village's water and sanitary sewer conveyance systems; all public parks; all
streets and sidewalks and the drainage thereof; and all Public Works vehicles,
equipment and buildings with the exception of those items specifically placed
under another department or department supervisor; (Ord. 2014-14, 6-5-2014)
         b.   Be responsible for the direct supervision, subject to the general
supervision of the Mayor and Mayor designee and the Village Administrator, of
the heads or supervisors of Public Works and Public Works employees; (Ord.
2014-14, 6-5-2014; amd. Ord. 2017-20, 4-20-2017)
         c.   Oversee the general administrative activities and projects
necessary to maintain the Public Works functions and operations; (Ord. 2014-14,
6-5-2014)
         d.   Recommend to the Mayor, the Village Administrator, and Board of
Trustees such measures deemed in the best interest of the Village Public Works
Departments and operations; (Ord. 2014-14, 6-5-2014; amd. Ord. 2017-20, 4-20-
2017)
         e.   Implement and carry out the direction and procedures established
by the Mayor or by ordinance or resolution of the Board of Trustees;
         f.   Assist in the planning and supervision of the Village streets and
alleys, sewer and water functions;
         g.   When requested, attend the meetings of the Board of Trustees,
standing committees of the Village, and other various Village boards and
commissions, with authority to participate and assist in the discussions, but
without right to vote;
         h.   Prepare a biweekly typed status report of the status of the
Public Works Departments and other topics pertinent to the efficient operation
of the Village Public Works to the Mayor and Board of Trustees;
         i.   Keep current inventory of all real and personal property of the
Village Public Works Departments;
         j.   Maintain and provide accurate information and reports to the
Budget Officers and supervisors of the Public Works Departments; and
         k.   Perform other duties as may be required by the Board of Trustees
or administration consistent with law and ordinances of the Village.
      2.   Personnel Duties:
         a.   Manage Public Works personnel functions and ensure compliance
with all applicable Federal and State employment and labor laws and
regulations;
         b.   Recruit, screen and evaluate all candidates for employment with
the Village Public Works Departments;
         c.   Prepare performance reviews for heads or supervisors of the
Public Works for presentation to administration and the Board of Trustees for
review and approval;
         d.   Administer Village personnel procedures and policies and
recommend changes of such to the Board of Trustees when deemed appropriate; and
         e.   Such other duties and responsibilities as may be necessary and
appropriate for the proper operation and personnel items of the Public Works
Department that may arise.
(Ord. 2014-14, 6-5-2014)
ARTICLE M. ZONING ADMINISTRATOR
SECTION :
1-8M-1: Creation And Compensation
1-8M-2: Oath And Bond
1-8M-3: Powers And Duties
1-8M-4: Inspections ; Right Of Entry
1-8M-5: Stop Work Orders
1-8M-6: Appeals
1-8M-1: CREATION AND COMPENSATION:
   There is hereby created the position of Zoning Administrator. The Zoning
Administrator shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of
the Board of Trustees. Compensation, if any, shall be determined by the Board
of Trustees as outlined in the annual budget or wage and salary ordinance. This
position is intended to be a part of the duties and responsibilities of the
Building Inspector and grounds maintenance position as well as potentially the
code compliance officer position.
(Ord. 2024-01, 1-18-2024)
1-8M-2: OATH AND BOND:
   Due to the exposure of this position to confidential matters of the village,
a Zoning Administrator, before performing the duties of the position, shall
execute a bond with sureties in such amount to be determined by the village
Board of Trustees conditioned upon the faithful performance of the building
inspector's duties and responsibilities. If a Zoning Administrator is also a
building inspector and grounds maintenance employee or code compliance officer,
a new bond shall not be required. A Zoning Administrator shall take the oath of
office prescribed by statute1.
(Ord. 2024-01, 1-18-2024)
1   See 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25.
1-8M-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   The Zoning Administrator shall administer and enforce the Village Zoning
Code as amended from time to time, and as in effect in accordance with the
powers and duties therein set forth, and in furtherance of such authority,
shall have the duties and responsibilities as hereinafter set forth, which
include, but are not limited to:
   A.   General Duties:
      1.   Conduct inspections of buildings, structures and land to determine
compliance with the Zoning Code and notify, in writing, the person responsible
for any violation found, indicating the nature of the violation and ordering
the action necessary to correct it;
      2.   Order the discontinuance of illegal use of land, buildings or
structures; removal of illegal buildings or structures or of illegal additions,
alterations or structural changes, discontinuance of any illegal work being
done; or shall take any other action authorized by statute or by the Zoning
Code to ensure compliance with or to prevent violation of its provisions;
      3.   Prepare, or coordinate the preparation of, and cause to be published
on or before March 31 of each year, a map showing the existing zoning uses,
divisions, restrictions, regulations and classifications in effect on the
preceding December 31;
      4.   Maintain permanent and current records of the Zoning Code including,
but not limited to, all maps, amendments, special use permits, planned building
developments, variances, appeals and applications therefor;
      5.   Provide and maintain a source of public information relative to
matters ari sing out of the Zoning Code;
      6.   Receive, file and forward to the Planning Commission all
applications for amendments, use variances and special use permits, and other
matters upon which the Plan Commission is required to act under the Zoning
Code;
      7.   Receive, file and forward to the Zoning Board of Appeals all
applications for variances, appeals and other matters upon which the Board is
required to act under the Zoning Code along with a review letter of each zoning
application to the Zoning Board of Appeals, applying the applicant's zoning
application to each applicable standard of review and making recommendations
thereto related;
      8.   Periodically review the Zoning Code for currentness and
appropriateness, and prepare written recommendations for any appropriate
changes if deemed necessary and appropriate;
      9.   Keep the Mayor and Village Board of Trustees advised of zoning
activities by written report from time to time, including statements of permits
and certificates issued and orders promulgated;
      10.   The Zoning Administrator may request and shall receive so far as
may be necessary in the discharge of his or her duties, the assistance and
cooperation of the Chief of Police in enforcing orders, of the Village Attorney
in prosecuting violators, and of other village officials, officers and
employees.
(Ord. 2024-01, 1-18-2024)
1-8M-4: INSPECTIONS; RIGHT OF ENTRY:
   A.   A Zoning Administrator, in the discharge of his or her official duties
and upon proper certification, shall have the authority to enter any building,
structure or premises at any reasonable hour.
   B.   A Zoning Administrator, when performing and completing inspections in
his or her formal capacity, shall not be responsible for determining or
advising persons of violations of all laws relating to the condition,
construction, repair, alteration, addition or maintenance of buildings and
structures. Failure of a Zoning Administrator to strictly enforce any law
relating to the condition, construction, repair, alteration, addition or
maintenance of buildings and structures, or zoning adherence to the Zoning Code
and laws, shall not relieve any person or corporation from adhering to those
laws nor from being responsible for any damage, repair or reconstruction that
may be required as a result of the failure to comply with any laws relating to
the condition, construction, repair, alteration, addition or maintenance of
buildings and structures, or compliance with the Zoning Code or zoning laws of
the State of Illinois.
(Ord. 2024-01, 1-18-2024)
1-8M-5: STOP WORK ORDERS:
   A Zoning Administrator shall have the power to order work stopped on the
construction, alteration, or repair of any building, structure or premises when
such work is being done in violation of the Zoning Code. Work shall not be
resumed after the issuance of such a stop order except upon written permission
of a Zoning Administrator; provided, that if the stop order is issued verbally,
it shall be followed by a written stop order within a reasonable time of the
verbal order. Such written stop order may be served by a Zoning Administrator,
any other authorized employee or official, or by any poli ce officer of the
Village.
(Ord. 2024-01, 1-18-2024)
1-8M-6: APPEALS:
   Appeals for administrative orders, requirements, decisions, or
determinations made by a Zoning Administrator shall be made to the Zoning Board
of Appeals as set forth in Section
11-5-7 of the Zoning Code.
(Ord. 2024-01, 1-18-2024)
CHAPTER 9
VILLAGE EMPLOYEES AND PERSONNEL
ARTICLE A. OFFICE MANAGER
SECTION:
1-9A-1: Creation And Compensation
1-9A-2: Oath And Bond
1-9A-3: Qualifications
1-9A-4: Duties
1-9A-1: CREATION AND COMPENSATION:
There is hereby created the Office of Village Office Manager. The Office
Manager shall be appointed by ordinance by the Board of Trustees. Compensation
shall be determined by the Board of Trustees as outlined in the annual
Appropriation or Salary Ordinance. (Ord. 2015-04, 1-22-2015)
1-9A-2: OATH AND BOND:
Due to the confidential nature of this office, the Office Manager shall, before
entering upon the duties of office, execute a bond with sureties in such amount
to be fixed by resolution and approved by the Board of Trustees conditioned
upon the faithful performance of the Office Manager's duties. The Office
Manager shall take the same oath of office prescribed by statute for Village
Treasurer. (Ord. 2015-04, 1-22-2015)
1-9A-3: QUALIFICATIONS:
The Office Manager should have the following qualifications:
   A.   Supervisor/Management Training: A background or prior experience in
supervising or management, preferable in a business office setting, including
supervision of personnel.
   B.   Accounting/Finance: A background or prior experience in finance or
accounting is preferred.
   C.   Human Resource: A background in human resource laws, requirements and
practice is also preferred. (Ord. 2015-04, 1-22-2015)
   D.   Residency: Shall reside within twenty five (25) miles of the Village
corporate limits unless otherwise specifically approved by the Village Board of
Trustees. (Ord. 2017-38, 5-18-2017)
1-9A-4: DUTIES:
The duties of the Office Manager shall include, but are not limited to:
   A.   General Duties:
      1.   Oversee, subject to the general direction proscribed by the Mayor,
executive assistant to the Mayor or other such similar supervisor, and the
Board of Trustees or a designee of the Board of Trustees, the day-to-day
operations and functions of the designated government building of the Village;
      2.   Administer and coordinate the billing for the water, sewer, and
other such utility accounts of the Village;
      3.   Maintain and provide accurate information and reports to the
supervisors of the Public Works Departments, Chief of Police, Budget Officer,
Treasurer, Village administration and Board related to the general affairs,
finance, and office operations of the Village;
      4.   Oversee the filing, payroll, finance data entry and reporting, Board
and other meeting preparation, event activities coordination and preparation,
and general day-to- day operations of the Village;
      5.   Be, oversee and coordinate the human resource obligations and needs
of the Village;
      6.   When requested, attend the meetings of the Board of Trustees,
standing committees of the Village, and other various Village boards and
commissions, with authority to participate and assist in the discussions, but
without the right to vote;
      7.   Prepare a biweekly typed status report of the status of the office
of the Village and other topics pertinent to the efficient operation of the
office of the Village to the Board of Trustees;
      8.   Perform other such duties that are appropriate for the proper
conduct and operation of the affairs of the Village; and
      9.   Perform other such duties as may be required by the Board of
Trustees consistent with law and ordinances of the Village.
   B.   Personnel Duties:
      1.   Shall supervise and oversee that the office staff adhere to and
carry out the lawful policies and directives issued by the Village
administration and/or Board;
