      2.   Shall take appropriate measures to assure the appropriate function
of the office and office staff of the Village;
      3.   Recruit, screen and evaluate all candidates for employment with the
Village office personnel;
      4.   Develop work schedule plans for the Village office employees and
supervise implementation of those work schedule plans;
      5.   Prepare all Village office employee performance reviews for
presentation to the Board of Trustees for review and approval; and
      6.   Administer Village personnel procedures and policies and recommend
changes of such to the Board of Trustees when deemed appropriate. (Ord. 2015-
04, 1-22-2015)
ARTICLE B. CUSTODIAN OF BUILDINGS AND GROUNDS
SECTION:
1-9B-1: Created; Compensation
1-9B-2: Bond And Oath
1-9B-3: Position Defined
1-9B-4: Qualifications
1-9B-5: Duties
1-9B-1: CREATED; COMPENSATION:
There is hereby created the Office of Village Custodian of Buildings and
Grounds. The Custodian of Buildings and Grounds shall be approved by the Mayor
and the Board of Trustees. Compensation shall be determined by the Board of
Trustees as outlined in the annual budget. (Ord. 2009-82, 6-15-2009; amd. 2011
Code)
1-9B-2: BOND AND OATH:
Due to the exposure of this office to confidential matters of the Village, the
Custodian of Buildings and Grounds, before performing the duties of office,
shall execute a bond with sureties in such amount to be fixed by resolution and
approved by the Board of Trustees, conditioned upon the faithful performance of
the custodian's duties and responsibilities. The Custodian of Buildings and
Grounds shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute 1 . (Ord. 2009-82,
6-15-2009)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25.
1-9B-3: POSITION DEFINED:
The Custodian of Buildings and Grounds shall be either fulfilled by part time
employees, a three-quarter time employee, or a full time employee who is
scheduled to work in compliance with the "Village Employee Personnel Policy and
Handbook". (Ord. 2012-11, 3-15-2012)
1-9B-4: QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   Skills, Licenses, And Abilities: The Custodian of Buildings and Grounds
shall possess the following skills, licenses, and abilities:
      1.   A valid Class B Illinois commercial driver's license.
      2.   Any required Illinois pesticide spraying licenses needed by the
Village.
      3.   The ability to operate and maintain a variety of equipment and
vehicles, including, but not limited to, pickups, utility terrain vehicles,
boom trucks and backhoes.
      4.   Possess basic math skills with the ability to provide accurate
estimates of materials and supplies required for building maintenance projects
and maintain records related thereto.
   B.   Knowledge: The Custodian of Buildings and Grounds shall have knowledge
of the following:
      1.   Standard tools, cleaning methods, practices and materials involved
in the remodeling, maintenance and repair of buildings, facilities, parks and
playgrounds; and
      2.   Hazards and safety precautions of the work involved in buildings or
grounds maintenance.
   C.   Abilities: The Custodian of Buildings and Grounds shall have the
following abilities:
      1.   Work well without close supervision and meet the requests of various
supervisors;
      2.   Communicate effectively with other employees using courtesy and good
judgment;
      3.   Complete job tasks in a prescribed period of time or ask for help
when the situation demands;
      4.   Safely use/operate tools and machinery, climb ladders, lift
equipment and/or supplies and materials; and
      5.   Respond to calls after scheduled work hours and/or on weekends, if
needed.
   D.   Physical Capabilities: The Custodian of Buildings and Grounds shall
have the following physical capabilities:
      1.   Safely perform necessary manual labor.
      2.   Perform heavy lifting and carrying of objects weighing at least
sixty (60) pounds.
      3.   Perform occasional lifting, pushing and pulling of objects weighing
up to one hundred (100) pounds.
      4.   The ability to work in hot or cold weather, above ground level on
roofs or attics, and belowground in crawl spaces, or working in confined
spaces. (Ord. 2009-82, 6-15-2009)
   E.   Residency: Shall reside within twenty five (25) miles of the Village
corporate limits unless otherwise specifically approved by the Village Board of
Trustees. (Ord. 2017-33, 5-18-2017)
1-9B-5: DUTIES:
The duties of the Custodian of Buildings and Grounds shall include, but are not
limited to:
   A.   Under the general supervision of the Mayor or designee, perform work
involving the cleaning, repair and maintenance of Village buildings or
facilities;
   B.   Perform maintenance on the grounds, sidewalks, and parks; oversee,
subject to the general direction proscribed by the Mayor and Board of Trustees
or a designee of the Board of Trustees, the day to day operations and functions
of the designated government building of the Village;
   C.   When requested, attend the meetings of the Board of Trustees, standing
committees of the Village, and other various Village boards and commissions,
with authority to participate and assist in the discussions, but without the
right to vote;
   D.   Perform and/or assist in carpentry, painting, plumbing, electrical,
concrete and other similar tasks relating to the repair and maintenance of
Village owned buildings and facilities;
   E.   Maintain inventories and complete records of all work performed;
   F.   Maintain and provide accurate information and reports of inventory to
the Budget Officer and supervisors of the various Village departments;
   G.   Be able to use/operate tools and machinery that are commonly used in
the performance of building and grounds maintenance;
   H.   Maintain, move or assemble furniture, computer equipment and wiring;
   I.   Perform preventative maintenance for plumbing, heating, ventilation and
air conditioning equipment including replacing belts and changing filters;
   J.   Perform other such duties that are appropriate for the proper conduct
and operation of the affairs of the Village; and
   K.   Perform such other duties as may be required by the Mayor or designee
consistent with law and ordinances of the Village. (Ord. 2009-82, 6-15-2009)
ARTICLE C. PROBATIONARY POLICE OFFICER
SECTION:
1-9C-1: Created
1-9C-2: Employment And Tenure
1-9C-3: Compensation
1-9C-4: Village Police Officer
1-9C-1: CREATED:
There is hereby created the position of probationary police officer. (Ord.
2007-06, 3-5-2007)
1-9C-2: EMPLOYMENT AND TENURE:
The village may hire individuals and employ them as probationary police
officers. The tenure of a probationary police officer shall be for a period of
six (6) months. (Ord. 2007-06, 3-5-2007)
1-9C-3: COMPENSATION:
The rate of pay for a probationary police officer shall be thirteen dollars
($13.00) per hour. (Ord. 2007-06, 3-5-2007)
1-9C-4: VILLAGE POLICE OFFICER:
In all other aspects, the position of probationary police officer shall be the
same as a village police officer. (Ord. 2007-06, 3-5-2007)
ARTICLE D. CODE COMPLIANCE OFFICER
SECTION:
1-9D-1: Created; Compensation
1-9D-2: Bond And Oath
1-9D-3: Position Defined
1-9D-4: Qualifications
1-9D-5: Duties
1-9D-6: Inspections; Right Of Entry
1-9D-7: Stop Work Orders
1-9D-1: CREATED; COMPENSATION:
There is hereby created the Office of Code Compliance Officer. The Code
Compliance Officer shall be approved by the Mayor and the Board of Trustees.
Compensation shall be determined by the Board of Trustees as outlined in the
annual budget. (Ord. 2010-01, 2-1-2010; amd. 2011 Code)
1-9D-2: BOND AND OATH:
Due to the exposure of this office to confidential matters of the Village, the
Code Compliance Officer, before performing the duties of office, shall execute
a bond with sureties in such amount to be fixed by resolution and approved by
the Board of Trustees, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the Code
Compliance Officer's duties and responsibilities. The Code Compliance Officer
shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute 1 . (Ord. 2010-01, 2-1-
2010)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25.
1-9D-3: POSITION DEFINED:
The Code Compliance Officer may be either an employee or independent contractor
with the Village, which shall be set forth at the time of approval. (Ord. 2010-
01, 2-1-2010; amd. Ord. 2020-05, 2-20-2020)
1-9D-4: QUALIFICATIONS:
The Code Compliance Officer must meet the following qualifications:
   A.   Skills, Licenses, And Abilities: Possess:
      1.   A license in either engineering or architecture; or
      2.   A certificate recognized by the State of Illinois and the Village
for building and home inspection.
   B.   Residency: Shall reside within twenty five (25) miles of the Village
corporate limits unless otherwise specified by an agreement with the Board of
Trustees. (Ord. 2010-01, 2-1-2010; amd. Ord. 2017-45, 5-18-2017; Ord. 2020-05,
2-20-2020)
1-9D-5: DUTIES:
The duties of the Code Compliance Officer shall include, but are not limited
to, the following:
   A.   Enforce, by all appropriate means, all laws and ordinances of the
Village relating to the condition, construction, repair, alteration, addition
or maintenance of buildings and structures, including the Building and Housing
Codes (title 10, chapter 1 of this Code) and the Zoning Ordinance (title 11 of
this Code);
   B.   Review applications for building and occupancy permits pursuant to
title 10 of this Code;
   C.   Coordinate and conduct inspections of properties for which a building
or occupancy permit is requested;
   D.   Coordinate and cooperate with the Randolph Township Fire District Life
Safety Code Compliance Officer pursuant to title 10 of this Code;
   E.   When requested, attend the meetings of the Board of Trustees, standing
committees of the Village, and other various Village boards and commissions,
with authority to participate and assist in the discussions, but without the
right to vote;
   F.   Perform other such duties that are appropriate for the proper conduct
and operation of the affairs of the Village related to the position; and
   G.   Be the designated Zoning Administrating Official if the position of
Zoning Administrating Official is not otherwise filled. (Ord. 2010-01, 2-1-
2010; amd. Ord. 2020-05, 2-20-2020)
1-9D-6: INSPECTIONS; RIGHT OF ENTRY:
   A.   The Code Compliance Officer, in the discharge of his official duties
and upon proper certification, shall have the authority to enter any building,
structure or premises at any reasonable hour.
   B.   The Code Compliance Officer, when performing and completing inspections
in his formal capacity, shall not be responsible for determining or advising
persons of violations of all laws relating to the condition, construction,
repair, alteration, addition or maintenance of buildings and structures.
Failure of the Code Compliance Officer to strictly enforce any law relating to
the condition, construction, repair, alteration, addition or maintenance of
buildings and structures shall not relieve any person or corporation from
adhering to those laws nor from being responsible for any damage, repair or
reconstruction that may be required as a result of the failure to comply with
any laws relating to the condition, construction, repair, alteration, addition
or maintenance of buildings and structures. (Ord. 2010-01, 2-1-2010)
1-9D-7: STOP WORK ORDERS:
The Code Compliance Officer shall have the power to order work stopped on the
construction, alteration, or repair of any building, structure or premises when
such work is being done in violation of any ordinance. Work shall not be
resumed after the issuance of such a stop order except upon written permission
of the Code Compliance Officer; provided, that if the stop order is issued
verbally, it shall be followed by a written stop order within one hour of the
verbal order. Such written stop order may be served by the Code Compliance
Officer or any police officer of the Village. (Ord. 2010-01, 2-1-2010)
ARTICLE E. POLICE DEPARTMENT AND OFFICERS
SECTION:
1-9E-1: Creation Of Police Department
1-9E-2: Oath And Bond
1-9E-3: General Qualifications
1-9E-4: General Duties
1-9E-5: Residency
1-9E-6: Compensation
1-9E-7: Chief Of Police
1-9E-7.5: Deputy Marshal (Deputy Chief Of Police)
1-9E-8: Police Sergeant
1-9E-9: Police Corporal
1-9E-10: Full-Time Police Officers
1-9E-11: Part-Time Police Officers
1-9E-12: General Requirements
1-9E-1: CREATION OF POLICE DEPARTMENT:
There is hereby created the Heyworth Police Department, an executive department
of the Village of Heyworth. This department shall consist of those police
officers as may be hereinafter provided for and that may be established by
action of the Mayor and Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2014-28, 11-20-2014)
1-9E-2: OATH AND BOND:
Due to the exposure of this office to confidential matters of the Village, all
police officers, before entering into and performing the duties of the
position, shall execute a bond with sureties in such amount to be fixed by
resolution and approved by the Board of Trustees conditioned upon the faithful
performance of the duties and responsibilities of that position. Police
officers shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute 1 . (Ord. 2014-28,
11-20-2014)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25.
1-9E-3: GENERAL QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   Minimum Qualifications: All police officers shall have, at a minimum,
the following qualifications to be eligible to be a police officer of the
Village:
      1.   Be a citizen of the United States;
      2.   Be at least twenty one (21) years of age;
      3.   Be a high school graduate or the equivalent;
      4.   Possess a valid Illinois driver's license;
      5.   Possess a current Illinois firearms owner identification card
(FOID);
      6.   Have no felony criminal record; and if there is a misdemeanor
criminal record, a copy of the record should be submitted with the written
application and an explanation if required by the Chief of Police to explain
all circumstances of record;
      7.   Submit fingerprints for examination by Illinois State Police Bureau
of Identification and Federal Bureau of Investigation;
      8.   May be required to submit to a physical examination and be found
drug free and in good general health;
      9.   Be proficient in typical police weaponry and meet department
firearms qualification requirements;
      10.   Pass a written exam if the Village Board of Trustees, Chief of
Police, or Mayor or designee elects to administer a standard entry level law
enforcement test;
      11.   Submit to an oral interview, if deemed appropriate, before the
Mayor and Board of Trustees or its designees;
      12.   Be qualified to enter and successfully complete any training
mandated by the Illinois Law Enforcement Training Standards Board, have
sufficient prior experience and training to qualify for a waiver from the
Illinois Law Enforcement Training and Standards Board, or have sufficient prior
experience and training, which together with some additional experience and
training would qualify for a waiver from said board and this to be determined
by the Chief of Police; and
      13.   Submit a written application and/or resume to the Chief of Police.
   B.   At-Will Employees: All police officers, except the Chief of Police, are
considered as at-will employees of the Village of Heyworth. (Ord. 2014-28, 11-
20-2014)
1-9E-4: GENERAL DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the members of the Police Department to see to the
enforcement of all ordinances of the Village, of all statutes effective and
applicable to the Village, and to preserve order and prevent infractions of the
law and to arrest violators thereof. Every member of the Police Department is
hereby declared to be a conservator of the peace. (Ord. 2014-28, 11-20-2014)
1-9E-5: RESIDENCY:
Anything in this Code to the contrary notwithstanding, no member of the Police
Department shall be required to be a resident of the Village but all full-time
police officers at all times while employed by the Village and all applicants
for a position as a police officer shall reside within twenty five (25) miles
of the corporate limits of the Village and all part-time officers shall reside
within fifty (50) miles of the corporate limits of the Village unless otherwise
agreed by way of action by the Village Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2014-28, 11-20-
2014)
1-9E-6: COMPENSATION:
Compensation for all police officers shall be determined by the Board of
Trustees as outlined in the annual Budget and/or Salary Ordinance. (Ord. 2014-
28, 11-20-2014)
1-9E-7: CHIEF OF POLICE:
The position of Chief of Police is established and defined pursuant to chapter
8, article E of this title. (Ord. 2014-28, 11-20-2014)
1-9E-7.5: DEPUTY MARSHAL (DEPUTY CHIEF OF POLICE):
   A.   Appointment, Term And Compensation: The Village Deputy Marshal (or
Deputy Chief of Police) shall be appointed by nomination of the Village Marshal
(Chief of Police) and approved with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees. The appointment of Deputy Chief of Police shall not qualify the
position or appointee as an appointed official pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/3.1-30-5. The Deputy Chief of Police shall serve at the discretion
of the Chief of Police and may be removed by the Chief of Police by appointment
of a new Deputy Chief or by cause. If the Deputy Chief of Police is removed,
that employee shall revert to the previously held position of that employee
prior to appointment unless the employee is terminated pursuant to Village
policies and procedures. The appointment shall be effective through and
including the date of expiration of the term of Chief of Police unless removal
occurs as hereinbefore set forth. Compensation shall be determined by the Board
of Trustees as outlined in the annual appropriation or salary ordinance.
   B.   Qualifications: The Village Deputy Chief of Police must have the
following qualifications:
      1.   A minimum of five (5) years continuous full-time law enforcement
experience is required, not necessarily with the Heyworth Police Department;
and
      2.   All other requirements for police officers of the Village.
      3.   Residency: Shall reside within twenty five (25) miles of the Village
corporate limits unless otherwise specified by an agreement with the Board of
Trustees.
   C.   Powers And Duties:
      1.   The following are the general powers and authority of the Deputy
Chief:
         a.   Receive direction from and be under the direct authority of the
Chief of Police;
         b.   Exercise direct authority over all full-time and part-time police
personnel, activities, facilities and equipment;
         c.   Assume command of the Heyworth Police Department in the
unavailability, incapacity or direction of the Chief of Police;
         d.   Shall serve as staff to the Chief of Police; and
         e.   All acts and decision of the Deputy Chief are subject to review
and amendment by the Chief of Police.
      2.   The following are the general responsibilities of the Deputy Chief:
         a.   Assist in the formulation of department objectives;
         b.   Assist in the development of plans to accomplish objective and
coordination of all departmental activities;
         c.   Establish, revise as needed, and implement departmental operation
programs;
         d.   Direct and coordinate the activities of department personnel,
both full-time and part-time;
         e.   Direct and coordinate the training of all officers;
         f.   Be responsible for the preparation, coordination and
implementation of special mobilization plans (i.e. disasters, VIP security,
special event planning and other special events and details involving personnel
as directed);
         g.   Ensure proper care utilization of all departmental equipment;
         h.   Promote the development of knowledge, ability and confidence of
department officers and help enhance the effectiveness and reputation of the
Heyworth Police Department;
         i.   Supervise all officer activities to ensure they are conducting
themselves in accordance with existing policies and orders in the most
effective and efficient manner;
         j.   Be familiar with the departmental operating budget, budget
projections and spending policy set forth by the Village;
         k.   Perform other duties necessary for the Heyworth Police Department
as directed by the Chief of Police; and
         l.   Such other duties and responsibilities as defined for police
officers of the Village. (Ord. 2020-09, 2-20-2020)
1-9E-8: POLICE SERGEANT:
   A.   Creation: There is hereby created the position of Police Sergeant. The
Police Sergeant shall be hired by recommendation of the Chief of Police and
with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees.
   B.   Duties: The Police Sergeant, which shall be the rank immediately below
the Chief of Police, shall be the immediate supervisor over all full-time
police officers and the Police Corporal. The Police Sergeant shall carry out
those lawful orders provided to him or her by the Chief of Police or by lawful
orders of the Mayor to suppress disorder or keep the peace. (Ord. 2014-28, 11-
20-2014)
1-9E-9: POLICE CORPORAL:
   A.   Creation: There is hereby created the position of Police Corporal. The
Police Corporal shall be hired by recommendation of the Chief of Police and
with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees.
   B.   Duties: The Police Corporal shall be the immediate supervisor over
part-time officers only and shall carry-out those lawful orders given to him or
her by the Police Sergeant and Chief of Police or by lawful orders of the Mayor
to suppress disorder or keep the peace. (Ord. 2014-28, 11-20-2014)
1-9E-10: FULL-TIME POLICE OFFICERS:
   A.   Creation: There is hereby created the position of a full-time police
officer. A full-time police officer shall be hired by recommendation of the
Chief of Police and with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees.
   B.   Probationary Police Officers: All new full-time police officers, which
includes police officers not currently employed by the Village or not
previously employed as a full-time police officer by the Village within the
last three (3) years, shall be probationary full-time police officers as
defined in the Village Personnel Policy and subject to the requirements therein
contained. (Ord. 2014-28, 11-20-2014)
   C.   Lead Officer: In the event the Chief of Police is incapacitated or
unable to perform his duties, the Chief of Police, or if the Chief of Police is
unable to do so, the Village Administrator, may temporarily designate a full-
time police officer as a "lead officer". As a lead officer, that officer can
perform the administrative responsibilities of the Chief of Police except for
those responsibilities prohibited by law or specifically prohibited by the
Chief of Police or Village Administrator. An officer designated as a lead
officer will receive additional compensation, while performing such duties, of
fifty cents ($0.50) per hour to his/her normal rate of pay. (Ord. 2017-76, 12-
7-2017)
1-9E-11: PART-TIME POLICE OFFICERS:
   A.   Creation: There is hereby created the position of part-time police
officer. Part-time police officers shall be hired by recommendation of the
Chief of Police and with advice and consent of the Board of Trustees.
   B.   Qualifications: All part-time officers, in addition to the other
qualifications and requirements listed in this chapter, shall be qualified to
enter and successfully complete any training mandated by the Illinois Law
Enforcement Training Standards Board.
   C.   Submittal Of This Article To The Illinois Law Enforcement Training
Standards Board: The aforesaid hiring standards, particularly with respect to
part-time police officers employed by the Village of Heyworth, shall be
submitted to the Illinois Law Enforcement Training Standards Board as is
required pursuant to section 3.1-30-21 of the Illinois Municipal Code 1 . (Ord.
2014-28, 11-20-2014)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-21.
1-9E-12: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Requirements: All police officers must:
      1.   Adherence To Personnel Policy And Other Policies: Adhere to and
abide by the Personnel Policy and Handbook of the Village and other such
applicable policies as provided for by the Mayor, Mayor designee, and/or Chief
of Police, or applicable State of Illinois or Federal laws.
      2.   Compliance With Work Instructions: Follow all lawful work
instructions given, and complete all assigned duties.
      3.   Adhere To Bloodborne Pathogen Policy: Be familiar with and adhere to
the Village Bloodborne Pathogen Policy.
      4.   NIMS Training: Complete and maintain appropriate National Incident
Management System (NIMS) training as is required by law.
      5.   Minimum Skills: Meet the minimum required skills, knowledge,
abilities and physical requirements as herein stated.
   B.   Required Skills, Knowledge, Abilities, And Physical Requirements:
      1.   Knowledge: Knowledge of:
         a.   Application and utilization of applicable computer systems.
         b.   Applicable Village ordinances, resolutions, and policies.
         c.   Appropriate State and Federal Criminal Statutes and evidentiary
procedures.
      2.   Abilities: Ability to:
         a.   Prepare appropriate police reports and other applicable legal
forms.
         b.   Have good communication skills and a calm demeanor, when
warranted, in responding to citizen questions and complaints and in dealing
with the general public in everyday activities as well as public officials and
supervisors.
         c.   Work outside in all weather conditions.
      3.   Mandatory Physical Requirements:
         a.   Meet, and if requested, pass testing, either before hire or while
employed, of general physical standards and minimal physical requirements,
which include, but are not limited to, the following physical standards and
examples thereof:
            (1)   Talking: Constantly. Express or exchange ideas by means of
the spoken word to impart oral information to other officers or the public and
convey detailed spoken instructions to others accurately, loudly or quickly.
            (2)   Standing: Constantly. The ability to stand for extended
periods of time, as may be necessary while taking police reports, communicating
with citizens, directing traffic, while on scene at accidents, or for other
various reasons.
            (3)   Sitting: Constantly. The ability to sit for extended periods
of time, as may be necessary while on routine patrol, preparing reports, or
completing necessary investigative measures.
            (4)   Running: Periodic. The ability to run as may be required in
order to pursue or to aid a person in the course of law enforcement activities.
            (5)   Lifting: Periodic. Officers may have to pick up or lift
persons if the person is not cooperative, to assist another officer in carrying
or dragging a person, if someone is injured, to transfer or take custody of
stolen property or other evidence such as television sets, computers, or other
heavy items, or perform such other lifting as is necessary to perform police
functions.
            (6)   Balancing: Constantly. Officers must be able to perform and
demonstrate simple balancing standards and tests, such as for field sobriety
examination associated with suspected intoxicated drivers, and to perform other
police functions in a safe and appropriate manner.
            (7)   Walking: Constantly. Being able to walk on foot for long
distances, for extended periods of time, and in an appropriate amount of time.
            (8)   Endurance/Moving About: Frequently physically move from
location to location for extended periods.
            (9)   Endurance/Overall Strength: Periodic. Exert force and/or lift
or carry objects weighing up to fifty (50) pounds regularly.
            (10)   Climbing: Periodic. Be able to climb stairs or elevated
surfaces using the legs and feet.
            (11)   Bending/Stooping: Periodic. Stoop by bending the body
downward or forward by flexing the spine at the waist, and/or bend by extending
the spine backward or from side to side.
            (12)   Kneeling/Crouching: Periodic. Kneel by bending the legs at
the knees to come to rest on the knee or knees, and/or crouch by bending the
body downward and forward by bending the legs and spine.
            (13)   Reaching: Constantly. Extend hands and arms in any
direction.
            (14)   Handling: Constantly. Seize, hold, grasp, turn or otherwise
work with the hand or hands.
            (15)   Rotation: Frequently. Twist and turn the spine or a ball and
socket joint such as the shoulder or hip.
            (16)   Hearing: Constantly. Perceive the nature of sounds by the
ear.
            (17)   Seeing: Constantly. Perceive the nature of sights by the
eyes.
            (18)   Reading: Read statutes, written reports, and instructions
with the eyes.
            (19)   Miscellaneous: Such other physical and mental abilities that
may be required to be a police officer.
         b.   The Village may utilize the physical standards and testing set
forth by the Peace Officer Wellness Evaluation Report (POWER) provide for by
the Illinois Law Enforcement Training and Standards Board, or any other
appropriate testing methods, procedures, or medical examinations in its
discretion to verify the minimum physical requirements hereinbefore set forth
or referenced can be met by each potential applicant or officer employed by the
Village as provided for by law. (Ord. 2014-28, 11-20-2014)
ARTICLE F. OFFICE STAFF
SECTION:
1-9F-1: Creation And Compensation
1-9F-2: Oath And Bond
1-9F-3: Qualifications
1-9F-4: Powers And Duties
1-9F-1: CREATION AND COMPENSATION:
There is hereby created the position of office staff. The office staff shall be
hired by ordinance by the Village Board of Trustees. Compensation shall be
determined by the Board of Trustees as outlined in the annual Appropriation
Ordinance. (Ord. 2013-23, 5-2-2013)
1-9F-2: OATH AND BOND:
Due to the confidential nature of this office and the information contained
therein, office staff shall, before entering upon the duties of office, execute
a bond with sureties in such amount to be fixed by resolution and approved by
the Board of Trustees conditioned upon the faithful performance of the office
staff's duties. The office staff shall take the same oath of office prescribed
by statute for Village Treasurer. (Ord. 2013-23, 5-2-2013)
1-9F-3: QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   Residency: The office staff shall reside within twenty five (25) miles
of the Village corporate limits unless otherwise specified by an agreement with
the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2017-37, 5-18-2017)
1-9F-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The duties of the office staff shall include, but are not limited to:
   A.   General Duties:
      1.   Assist with the filing, organization, bookkeeping, greeting and
addressing of general needs and questions of the public, and other such
secretarial duties;
      2.   Assist with the billing for the water, sewer and garbage accounts of
the Village;
      3.   Maintain and provide accurate information and reports of the various
departments;
      4.   Assist in preparation of various meetings and gatherings of the
Village;
      5.   Assist the Village Clerk, Village Treasurer, Village Board, various
department supervisors, administration, and various Village officials with
information, documentation, and organization to further the needs and
responsibilities of these various Village officials and employees without
disclosing confidential or improper information; and
      6.   Perform other such duties that are appropriate for the proper
conduct and operation of the affairs of the Village. (Ord. 2017-37, 5-18-2017)
ARTICLE G. PUBLIC WORKS EMPLOYEE
SECTION:
1-9G-1: Creation And Compensation
1-9G-2: Job Qualification Requirements
1-9G-3: Powers And Duties
1-9G-4: Classifications
1-9G-1: CREATION AND COMPENSATION:
There is hereby created the position of Public Works employee. A Public Works
employee shall be hired by action of the Village Board of Trustees with
recommendation from the Superintendent of Public Works or other such supervisor
of the Public Works Department and the Village Administrator. Compensation
shall be determined by the Board of Trustees as outlined in the annual
Appropriation Ordinance. (Ord. 2013-44, 10-3-2013)
1-9G-2: JOB QUALIFICATION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Mandatory General Requirements: Each Public Works employee must:
      1.   Be able to perform each duty hereinafter stated satisfactorily.
      2.   Have good communication skills and a calm demeanor in responding to
citizen questions and complaints and in dealing with the general public in
everyday activities.
      3.   Follow the lawful directives issued by the Superintendent of Public
Works or other appropriate supervisor or official of the Village.
      4.   Have the ability to work within established guidelines.
      5.   Have the ability to perform repetitious tasks.
      6.   Have the ability to use and operate pick-up trucks; tractors;
forklifts; lawnmowers; weedeaters; chain saws; chippers; blowers; various spray
equipment; and miscellaneous power tools for turf maintenance, carpentry,
painting, plumbing, and cement finishing work.
   B.   Mandatory Physical Requirements: Each Public Works employee must be
able to:
      1.   Endurance/Moving About: Frequently physically move from location to
location for extended periods.
      2.   Endurance/Overall Strength: Heavy work. Exert force and/or lift or
carry objects weighing up to fifty (50) pounds regularly.
      3.   Walking: Constantly walk and move about on foot for extended
periods.
      4.   Sitting: Frequently be able to sit for extended periods.
      5.   Lifting/Carrying: Periodic. Lift by manually raising or lowering an
object from one level to another (including upward pulling), and/or carry or
transport objects, usually holding items in the hands or arms or on the
shoulder.
      6.   Pushing/Pulling: Periodic. Push by exerting force on an object so
that it moves away from the force or worker (including, but not limited to,
slapping, striking, kicking, and treadle actions); and/or pull by exerting
force on an object so that it moves toward the force or worker (including
jerking).
      7.   Controls: Frequently. Use one or both arms and/or hands; use one or
either feet or legs to move controls on machinery or equipment.
      8.   Climbing: Periodic. Ascend or descend ladders, stairs, scaffolding,
ramps, poles, ropes, and the like using the feet and legs and/or hands and
arms.
      9.   Balancing: Periodic. Maintain body equilibrium to prevent falling
when walking, standing, crouching, or running on narrow, slippery or
erratically moving surfaces.
      10.   Bending/Stooping: Periodic. Stoop by bending the body downward or
forward by flexing the spine at the waist, and/or bend by extending the spine
backward or from side to side.
      11.   Kneeling/Crouching: Periodic. Kneel by bending the legs at the
knees to come to rest on the knee or knees, and/or crouch by bending the body
downward and forward by bending the legs and spine.
      12.   Crawling: Periodic. Move about on the hands and knees or hands and
feet.
      13.   Reaching: Constantly. Extend hands and arms in any direction.
      14.   Handling: Constantly. Seize, hold, grasp, turn or otherwise work
with the hand or hands.
      15.   Rotation: Frequently. Twist and turn the spine or a ball and socket
joint such as the shoulder or hip.
      16.   Talking: Constantly. Express or exchange ideas by means of the
spoken word to impart oral information to Village employees or officials or to
the public and convey detailed spoken instructions to other workers accurately,
loudly or quickly.
      17.   Hearing: Constantly. Perceive the nature of sounds by the ear.
      18.   Seeing: Constantly. Perceive the nature of sights by the eyes.
      19.   Reading: Read water meters, written reports, and instructions.
      20.   Writing: Ability to accurately record water meter readings, record
information and summary of events.
      21.   Miscellaneous: Such other physical and mental abilities that may be
required for the position. (Ord. 2013-44, 10-3-2013)
   C.   Residency: Shall reside within twenty five (25) miles of the Village
corporate limits unless otherwise specified by an agreement with the Board of
Trustees. (Ord. 2017-44, 5-18-2017)
1-9G-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The duties of the Public Works employees include, but are not limited to:
   A.   General Duties:
      1.   Repair, replace, patch, crack seal and maintain the A-3, bituminous
or other road surfaces owned by the Village;
      2.   Fill low places, pot holes, and ruts in road surfaces, shoulders or
rights-of-ways owned or maintained by the Village;
      3.   Repair, clean, install and maintain culverts, storm sewers, sanitary
sewers, gutters, ditches, and other drainage facilities owned or maintained by
the Village;
      4.   Clean and maintain Village owned bridges;
      5.   Perform hand mowing, mowing, and trimming of the various properties
owned or maintained by the Village, including, but not limited to, parks,
Village rights-of-way, and real property of the Village;
      6.   Collect and appropriately dispose of or compost brush and landscape
waste, except for grass trimmings and other such items specifically not
collected by the Village;
      7.   Sweep streets;
      8.   Read meters and assist in the operation and maintenance of the water
and sewerage distribution systems;
      9.   Maintain, repair and clean the Village parks, tennis courts, and
other Village properties;
      10.   Perform routine housekeeping duties, keeping stockpiles of
materials appropriately stocked and shaped, and such other tasks and
requirements associated with the general care of the Village buildings and
grounds;
      11.   Straighten, erect, and clean Village traffic signs;
      12.   Lubricate, service, make minor repairs or adjustments, or cause
maintenance to be performed on the Village equipment, including, but not
limited to, Village trucks, tractors, mowing and trimming machines, brush
chippers, construction equipment, snow plows, cinder spreaders, or any other
Public Works' vehicles or equipment;
      13.   Perform normal security measures by making sure all equipment,
tools, materials and property of the Village are secured at the end of each
work shift;
      14.   Prepare, complete and maintain necessary paperwork for operations
affiliated with the Public Works duties and responsibilities, which may
include, but is not limited to, records of materials, equipment usage,
inventory, hours worked, vehicle and equipment usage, and other assigned record
keeping;
      15.   Perform traffic control as needed;
      16.   Performs mechanical work as needed;
      17.   Performs occasional welding;
      18.   Works overtime as required to complete tasks;
      19.   Work weekends and odd hours when necessary;
      20.   Performs minor construction projects, carpentry, concrete and
janitorial services;
      21.   Assists with Code enforcement of garbage, brush, trees, etc.;
      22.   Have knowledge of and be familiar with all safety policies,
procedures, requirement or lawful safety directives that may be required or
imposed to perform the job duties and responsibilities of the Public Works
operations;
      23.   Perform all tasks while properly utilizing, wearing or otherwise
adhering to all safety policies, procedures, requirements or lawful safety
directives as may be required or imposed;
      24.   Work with and assist, where appropriate, other governmental bodies
or private entities that perform work on behalf, oversee, or work with the
Village;
      25.   Adhere to and comply with any lawful personnel policies,
ordinances, resolutions or other actions of the Village Board of Trustees, or
administrative or supervisor directives; and
      26.   Perform such other duties that are appropriate for the proper
conduct and operation of the affairs of the Village. (Ord. 2013-44, 10-3-2013)
1-9G-4: CLASSIFICATIONS:
   A.   Due to the various duties and responsibilities of the Public Works
Department, and the various requirements that may be necessary to complete some
of those duties and responsibilities, there is hereby created the following
worker classifications within the Public Works Department:
      1.   Seasonal Worker:
         a.   A seasonal Public Works employee is an unskilled worker whose job
duties shall meet the following minimum requirements:
            (1)   Work no more than six hundred (600) hours in a calendar year;
            (2)   Be at least sixteen (16) years of age;
            (3)   Maintain a valid driver's license to operate a motor vehicle
within the State of Illinois;
         b.   A seasonal Public Works employee shall be limited to the
following duties:
            (1)   Perform hand mowing, mowing, and trimming of the various
properties owned or maintained by the Village, including, but not limited to,
parks, Village rights-of-way, and real property of the Village;
            (2)   Maintain, repair and clean the Village parks, tennis courts,
and other Village properties;
            (3)   Have knowledge of and be familiar with all safety policies,
procedures, requirement or lawful safety directives that may be required or
imposed to perform the job duties and responsibilities of the Public Works
operations related to the duties of a seasonal worker;
            (4)   Perform all tasks while properly utilizing, wearing or
otherwise adhering to all safety policies, procedures, requirements or lawful
safety directives as may be required or imposed;
            (5)   Perform such other duties that are appropriate for a seasonal
employee in the Public Works Department of the Village; and
            (6)   Adhere to and comply with any lawful personnel policies,
ordinances, resolutions or other actions of the Village Board of Trustees, or
administrative or supervisor directives.
      2.   Part-Time Worker:
         a.   A Public Works employee classified as a part-time worker is an
unskilled worker whose job duties will consist of the general duties as
hereinbefore described and as assigned by the employee's supervisor from time
to time as deemed appropriate by the supervisor and shall have the minimum
following requirements:
            (1)   Be at least eighteen (18) years of age; and
            (2)   Maintain a valid driver's license to operate a motor vehicle
within the State of Illinois.
      3.   Village Worker I:
         a.   A Public Works employee classified as a Village Worker I is an
unskilled worker whose job duties will consist of the general duties as
hereinbefore described and as assigned by the employee's supervisor from time
to time as deemed appropriate by the supervisor.
         b.   A Village Worker I, in addition to adhering to the duties
hereinbefore described, must:
            (1)   Be at least eighteen (18) years of age;
            (2)   Maintain a valid driver's license to operate a motor vehicle
within the State of Illinois; and
            (3)   Maintain other licensing as is required in order to perform
the essential functions of the job duties assigned.
      4.   Village Worker II:
         a.   A Public Works employee classified as a Village Worker II is a
skilled worker whose job duties will consist of all of the requirements of a
Village Worker I in addition to maintaining a valid State of Illinois issued
CDL driver's license and performing snow plowing.
      5.   Village Worker III:
         a.   A Public Works employee classified as a Village Worker III is a
skilled worker whose job duties will consist of all of the requirements of a
Village Worker II in addition to having specific training or certification
approved by the Village to operate heavy machinery, which the type of heavy
machinery for the purpose of this article only includes, but is not limited to,
a back hoe, high hoe, forklift, skid loader, loader/tractor, etc.
      6.   Village Worker IV:
         a.   A Public Works employee classified as a Village Worker IV is a
skilled worker whose job duties will consist of all of the requirements of a
Village Worker II in addition to:
            (1)   Being a "lead worker" or a working supervisor that works
under the general supervision of the Superintendent of Public Works; and
            (2)   Obtaining and maintaining various additional licensing and/or
certification(s).
   B.   Any Public Works employee, regardless of classification, may be
assigned by the Superintendent of Public Works as the acting designee of the
Superintendent of Public Works, also referred to as a "temporary lead worker",
from time to time and as needed. Any employee designated as an acting lead
worker shall receive an additional twenty five cent ($0.25) wage increase for
the hours that employee is designated as a lead worker.
   C.   A Public Works employee will be classified as a Village Worker I when
initially employed unless specifically stated otherwise by action of the
Village Board when hired and may only advance in job classification if the
employee meets the qualifications for the job classification and only if the
advancement is recommended by the supervisor and approved by the Mayor or Mayor
designee and by action of the Village Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2013-44, 10-3-
2013)
ARTICLE H. SUPERINTENDENT OF WATER AND SANITATION
SECTION:
1-9H-1: Creation And Compensation
1-9H-2: Qualifications
1-9H-3: Employment Policies
1-9H-4: Powers And Duties
1-9H-1: CREATION AND COMPENSATION:
There is hereby created the position of Superintendent of Water and Sanitation
(or Water and Sewer Operator or Water and Sewer Supervisor or Public Works
Supervisor). The Superintendent of Water and Sanitation shall be hired by
action of the Village Board of Trustees with recommendation from the Director
of Public Works or other such appropriate supervisor of the Public Works
Department. Compensation shall be determined by the Board of Trustees as
outlined in the annual Budget or Salary Ordinance. (Ord. 2015-38, 8-20-2015;
amd. Ord. 2022-75, 12-15-2022)
1-9H-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
The Superintendent of Water and Sanitation must have the following
qualifications:
   A.   Experience: Prior experience or any equivalent combination of training
is preferred, with administrative qualifications in respect to controlling and
supervising operations, personnel and the functions of a Municipal Public Works
Department. (Ord. 2015-38, 8-20-2015)
   B.   Licensing: Shall have or shall have the ability to obtain, within an
agreed upon timeframe, at the time of hire appropriate licensing to operate the
water system as well as sewerage system of the Village. (Ord. 2017-61, 10-5-
2017)
   C.   Residency: Shall reside within twenty five (25) miles of the Village
corporate limits unless otherwise specifically approved by action of the Board
of Trustees. (Ord. 2017-31, 5-18-2017)
   D.   Mandatory General Requirements:
      1.   Be able to perform each duty hereinafter stated satisfactorily.
      2.   Have good communication skills and a calm demeanor in responding to
citizen questions and complaints and in dealing with the general public in
everyday activities.
      3.   Follow the lawful directives issued by the Director of Public Works
or other appropriate supervisor or official of the Village.
      4.   Have the ability to work within established guidelines.
      5.   Have the ability to perform repetitious tasks.
      6.   Have the ability to use and operate pick-up trucks; back hoes; pipe
installation equipment; heavy equipment as needed for proper water and
sanitation operations; and miscellaneous power tools for water and sewer
installations and operations.
      7.   Have the ability to perform the necessary chemical usage and
application as well as necessary procedures to assure proper operations of the
Village water system and sewer system.
   E.   Mandatory Physical Requirements: The Superintendent of Water and
Sanitation must be able to meet the physical requirements set forth for the
Public Works' employees. (Ord. 2015-38, 8-20-2015)
1-9H-3: EMPLOYMENT POLICIES:
The position of Superintendent of Water and Sanitation shall be subject to the
following employment policies, subject to amendment from time to time by the
Board of Trustees. The Superintendent of Water and Sanitation shall:
   A.   At the time of appointment, have all relevant details of employment
stated in the resolution of consent for hire by the Board of Trustees that are
not specifically provided for in this chapter, in the employee handbook, or any
policies and practices heretofore or hereinafter adopted by the Board of
Trustees;
   B.   During the term of office with the Village, accept no other employment
without the express permission of the Mayor and Board of Trustees, and shall
dedicate such time and effort as may be necessary to discharge all of the
duties and responsibilities of the position;
   C.   Devote not less than forty (40) hours per calendar week to such
employment and shall be available and accessible for receiving emergency calls
after normal business hours from the Mayor, members of the Board of Trustees,
Chief of Police and heads of other departments of the Village to provide
assistance, services, supervision and information regarding urgent
circumstances which may arise during such period;
   D.   Attend such continuing education, professional development and related
educational conferences, seminars and programs which are directly related to
the discharge of the duties of Water Superintendent and shall be reimbursed by
the Village at an amount not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per
fiscal year or such amount provided for in the Village budget, whichever is
less;
   E.   Receive such disability, health, dental and life insurance benefits as
may be provided to all other full time employees of the Village; and
   F.   Be credited for such vacation, sick and personal time as is provided to
all other full time employees of the Village, and as such may be amended from
time to time by the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2015-38, 8-20-2015)
1-9H-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Superintendent of Water and Sanitation shall perform all duties necessary
for the appropriate and efficient operation of the Public Works, subject to the
direction of the Water Superintendent's Supervisors or general authority of the
Village Board of Trustees, including, but not limited to, the sewerage, and
water infrastructures and operations. Such duties provided for in this section
may be supplemented, modified or amended by amendment of this chapter, or such
other necessary enactments or adoptions by the Mayor and the Board of Trustees
from time to time. In connection therewith, the Superintendent of Water and
Sanitation shall:
   A.   General Duties:
      1.   Be responsible for the direct supervision, subject to the general
supervision of the Director of Public Works, Superintendent of Public Works,
Village Administrator, Mayor or Mayor designee, of all Water and Sanitation
Department employees; and in the event that a Superintendent of Streets and
Drainage has not been designated, then this position shall be responsible for
the direct supervision over the Streets and Drainage employees as well; and
      2.   Oversee the activities and projects necessary to maintain the day-
to-day water, sewer, and storm sewer functions and operations;
      3.   Recommend to the Director of Public Works or other supervisor or
Board of Trustees such measures deemed in the best interest of the Village
Water and Sewer Departments and operations;
      4.   Implement and carry out the direction and procedures established by
the Director of Public Works or other Water Superintendent Supervisor or by
ordinance or resolution of the Board of Trustees;
      5.   Assist in the planning and supervision of the sewer and water
functions;
      6.   When requested, attend the meetings of the Board of Trustees,
standing committees of the Village, and other various Village boards and
commissions, with authority to participate and assist in the discussions, but
without right to vote;
      7.   Coordinate resources and personnel with other departments in Public
Works to ensure the efficient operation of the Public Works Department; and
      8.   Perform other duties as may be required by the Water
Superintendent's supervisors and action of the Board of Trustees consistent
with law and ordinances of the Village.
      9.   Assist with and working with the designated lead Code compliance
official to perform Code compliance enforcement in the Village.
   B.   Personnel Duties:
      1.   Assist with managing Water and Sanitation Department personnel
functions and ensure compliance with all applicable Federal and State
employment and labor laws and regulations;
      2.   Assist in the recruiting, screening and evaluating all candidates
for employment with the Village Water and Sanitation Department;
      3.   Assist with developing work schedule plans for the Water Department
employees, and supervise implementation of those work schedule plans;
      4.   Assist with Water and Sanitation Department employees performance
reviews for presentation to supervisors; and
      5.   Administer Village personnel procedures and policies and recommend
changes of such to the Director of Public Works when deemed appropriate. (Ord.
2015-38, 8-20-2015; amd. Ord. 2022-75, 12-15-2022)
ARTICLE I. SUPERINTENDENT OF STREETS AND DRAINAGE
SECTION:
1-9I-1: Creation And Compensation
1-9I-2: Qualifications
1-9I-3: Employment Policies
1-9I-4: Powers And Duties
1-9I-1: CREATION AND COMPENSATION:
There is hereby created the position of Superintendent of Streets and Drainage.
The Superintendent of Streets and Drainage shall be hired by action of the
Village Board of Trustees with recommendation from the Director of Public Works
or other such appropriate supervisor of the Public Works Department.
Compensation shall be determined by the Board of Trustees as outlined in the
annual Budget or Salary Ordinance. (Ord. 2015-39, 8-20-2015)
1-9I-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
The Superintendent of Streets and Drainage must meet the following
qualifications and standards:
   A.   Experience: Prior experience or any equivalent combination of training
is preferred, with administrative qualifications in respect to controlling and
supervising operations, personnel and the functions of a Municipal Public Works
Department with specific understanding or experience in construction,
maintenance, and planning of streets, alleys, rights-of-way, sidewalk,
stormwater detention, drainage, and parks. (Ord. 2015-39, 8-20-2015)
   B.   Residency: Shall reside within twenty five (25) miles of the Village
corporate limits unless otherwise specifically approved by the Board of
Trustees. (Ord. 2017-30, 5-18-2017)
   C.   Mandatory General Requirements: The Superintendent of Streets and
Drainage must:
      1.   Be able to perform each duty hereinafter stated satisfactorily.
      2.   Have good communication skills and a calm demeanor in responding to
citizen questions and complaints and in dealing with the general public in
everyday activities.
      3.   Follow the lawful directives issued by the Director of Public Works
or other appropriate supervisor or official of the Village.
      4.   Have the ability to work within established guidelines.
      5.   Have the ability to perform repetitious tasks.
      6.   Have the ability to use and operate pick-up trucks; tractors;
forklifts; lawnmowers; weedeaters; chain saws; chippers; blowers; various spray
equipment; heavy equipment as needed for proper street and drainage operations;
and miscellaneous power tools for turf maintenance, carpentry, painting,
plumbing, and cement finishing work.
   D.   Mandatory Physical Requirements: The Superintendent of Streets and
Drainage must be able to meet the physical requirements set forth for the
Public Works' employees. (Ord. 2015-39, 8-20-2015)
1-9I-3: EMPLOYMENT POLICIES:
The position of Superintendent of Streets and Drainage shall be subject to the
following employment policies, subject to amendment from time to time by the
Board of Trustees. The Superintendent of Streets and Drainage shall:
   A.   At the time of appointment, have all relevant details of employment
stated in the resolution of consent for hire by the Board of Trustees that are
not specifically provided for in this chapter, in the employee handbook, or any
policies and practices heretofore or hereinafter adopted by the Board of
Trustees;
   B.   During the term of office with the Village, accept no other employment
without the express permission of the Mayor and Board of Trustees, and shall
dedicate such time and effort as may be necessary to discharge all of the
duties and responsibilities of the position;
   C.   Devote not less than forty (40) hours per calendar week to such
employment and shall be available and accessible for receiving emergency calls
after normal business hours from the Mayor, members of the Board of Trustees,
Chief of Police and heads of other departments of the Village to provide
assistance, services, supervision and information regarding urgent
circumstances which may arise during such period;
   D.   Attend such continuing education, professional development and related
educational conferences, seminars and programs which are directly related to
the discharge of the duties of the Superintendent of Streets and Drainage and
shall be reimbursed by the Village at an amount not to exceed one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00) per fiscal year or such amount provided for in the Village
budget, whichever is less;
   E.   Receive such disability, health, dental and life insurance benefits as
may be provided to all other full time employees of the Village; and
   F.   Be credited for such vacation, sick and personal time as is provided to
all other full time employees of the Village, and as such may be amended from
time to time by the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2015-39, 8-20-2015)
1-9I-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Superintendent of Streets and Drainage shall perform all duties necessary
for the appropriate and efficient operation of the Street Department of the
Village, including, but not limited to, the streets, alleys, right-of-ways,
culverts, parks, stormwater detention and drainage. Such duties provided for in
this section may be supplemented, modified or amended by amendment of this
chapter, or such other necessary enactments or adoptions by the Mayor and the
Board of Trustees from time to time. In connection therewith, the
Superintendent shall:
   A.   General Duties:
      1.   Be responsible for the direct supervision, subject to the general
supervision of the Mayor or Mayor designee, Village Administrator, and Director
of Public Works, of Streets and Drainage Department ("street") employees;
      2.   Oversee the activities and projects necessary to maintain the day-
to-day street, rights-of-way (excluding general lawn maintenance if there is
another department maintaining such), culverts, and drainage functions and
operations;
      3.   Recommend to the Director of Public Works or other supervisor or
Board of Trustees such measures deemed in the best interest of the Street
Department and operations;
      4.   Implement and carry out the direction and procedures established by
any Street Department Supervisor or by ordinance or resolution of the Board of
Trustees;
      5.   Assist in the planning and supervision of the Village streets and
alleys, sewer, rights-of-way, sidewalks, and drainage;
      6.   When requested, attend the meetings of the Board of Trustees,
standing committees of the Village, and other various Village boards and
commissions, with authority to participate and assist in the discussions, but
without right to vote;
      7.   Coordinate resources and personnel with other departments in Public
Works to ensure the efficient operation of the Public Works Department; and
      8.   Perform other duties as may be required by the Superintendent of
Streets and Drainage Supervisors and action of the Board of Trustees consistent
with law and ordinances of the Village.
   B.   Personnel Duties:
      1.   Assist with managing Street Department personnel functions and
ensure compliance with all applicable Federal and State employment and labor
laws and regulations;
      2.   Assist in the recruiting, screening and evaluating all candidates
for employment with the Village Street Department;
      3.   Assist with developing work schedule plans for the Street Department
employees, and supervise implementation of those work schedule plans;
      4.   Assist with Street Department employees performance reviews for
presentation to supervisors; and
      5.   Administer Village personnel procedures and policies and recommend
changes of such to the Director of Public Works or other appropriate supervisor
when deemed appropriate. (Ord. 2015-39, 8-20-2015)
 
   CHAPTER 9
   VILLAGE EMPLOYEES AND PERSONNEL
ARTICLE J. BUILDING INSPECTOR AND GROUNDS MAINTENANCE EMPLOYEE
SECTION:
1-9J-1: Creation And Compensation
1-9J-2: Oath And Bond
1-9J-3: Position Defined
1-9J-4: Qualifications
1-9J-5: Powers And Duties
1-9J-6: Inspections; Right Of Entry
1-9J-7: Stop Work Orders
1-9J-1: CREATION AND COMPENSATION:
There is hereby created the position of village building inspector and grounds
maintenance, which may also be referred to as building inspector. This position
is similar to a code compliance officer that is primarily an employee of the
Building and Zoning Department but shall have duties and responsibilities that
are similar to a custodian of buildings and grounds that is under the Parks &
Recreation Department under the Public Works Department. A building inspector
and grounds maintenance employee shall be approved with the consent of the
mayor and the board of trustees. Compensation shall be determined by the board
of trustees as outlined in the annual budget or wage and salary ordinance.
(Ord. 2023-35, 7-6-2023)
1-9J-2: OATH AND BOND:
Due to the exposure of this position to confidential matters of the village, a
building inspector and grounds maintenance employee, before performing the
duties of the position, shall execute a bond with sureties in such amount to be
fixed by resolution and approved by the board of trustees conditioned upon the
faithful performance of the building inspector’s duties and responsibilities. A
building inspector employee shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute
1 . (Ord. 2023-35, 7-6-2023)
 
Notes
1 1. See 65 ILCS 5/3, 1-10-25
1-9J-3: POSITION DEFINED:
The building inspector and grounds maintenance employee shall be either a 3/
4 time employee or a full-time employee who is scheduled to work in compliance
with the Village Employee Personnel Policy and Handbook. (Ord. 2023-35, 7-6-
2023)
1-9J-4: QUALIFICATIONS:
The building inspector and grounds maintenance employee must possess and meet
the following qualifications, skills, physical requirements and abilities:
   A.   Professional Licenses or Certifications:
      1.   A professional license in either engineering or architecture; or
      2.   a.   Must possess or obtain within 12 months of hire certification
by the International Code Council as a Residential Building Inspector and
Commercial Building Inspector; and
         b.   Must possess or obtain within 18 months of hire a Commercial
Building Plans Examiner Certification.
   B.   Skills:
      1.   Using Microsoft Office products;
      2.   Using permitting software; and
      3.   Using GIS software.
   C.   Ability to:
      1.   Organize and prioritize workload;
      2.   Read building plans and specifications;
      3.   Critically apply building and construction code requirements and
ordinances of the Village;
      4.   Detect possible defects and faults at various stages in building
construction;
      5.   Work well without close supervision and meet the requests of various
supervisors;
      6.   Complete job tasks in a prescribed period of time or ask for help
when the situation demands;
      7.   Communicate and work effectively with other employees, other
government agencies, and the public;
      8.   Operate and help maintain a variety of equipment and vehicles,
including, but not limited to: pick-ups; utility-terrain vehicles; lawn care
equipment including lawnmowers, weed eaters and blowers; cleaning equipment;
and tools necessary for the general maintenance on buildings and grounds, parks
and playgrounds;
      9.   Work in hot or cold weather, above ground level on roofs or attics,
and below ground in crawl spaces, or working in confined spaces;
      10.   Have a good knowledge of the hazards and safety measures required
for the safe maintenance and operations of buildings and grounds, parks, and
playgrounds;
      11.   Perform necessary manual labor and safely use/operate tools and
machinery, climb ladders, lift equipment and/or supplies and materials;
      12.   Be able to use/operate tools and machinery that are commonly used
in the performance of buildings and grounds maintenance;
      13.   Have the ability to perform repetitious tasks;
      14.   Possess basic math skills with the ability to provide accurate
estimates of materials and supplies required for building maintenance projects
and maintain records related thereto; and
      15.   Respond to calls after scheduled work hours and/or on weekends if
needed; and
      16.   Meet the following minimum physical requirements:
         a.   Endurance/Moving About: Frequently physically move from location
to location for extended periods.
         b.   Endurance/Overall strength: Medium work. Exert force and/or lift
or carry objects weighing up to 50 pounds periodically.
         c.   Walking: Constantly. Walk and move about on foot for extended
periods.
         d.   Sitting: Frequently. Be able to sit for extended periods.
         e.   Lifting/Carrying: Periodic. Lift by manually raising or lowering
an object from one level to another (including upward pulling), and/or carry or
transport objects, usually holding items in the hands or arms or on the
shoulder.
         f.   Pushing/Pulling: Periodic. Push by exerting force on an object so
that it moves away from the force or worker (including, but not limited to,
slapping, striking, kicking, and treadle actions); and/or pull by exerting
force on an object so that it moves toward the force or worker (including
jerking).
         g.   Controls: Frequently. Use one or both arms and/or hands; use one
or either feet or legs to move controls on machinery or equipment.
         h.   Climbing: Periodic. Ascend or descend ladders, stairs,
scaffolding, ramps, poles, ropes, and the like using the feet and legs and/or
hands and arms.
         I.   Balancing: Periodic. Maintain body equilibrium to prevent falling
when walking, standing, crouching, or running on narrow, slippery or
erratically moving surfaces.
         j.   Bending/Stooping: Periodic. Stoop by bending the body downward or
forward by flexing the spine at the waist, and/or bend by extending the spine
backward or from side to side.
         k.   Kneeling/Crouching: Periodic. Kneel by bending the legs at the
knees to come to rest on the knee or knees, and/or crouch by bending the body
downward and forward by bending the legs and spine.
         l.   Crawling: Periodic. Move about on the hands and knees or hands
and feet.
         m.   Reaching: Constantly. Extend hands and arms in any direction.
         n.   Handling: Constantly. Seize, hold, grasp, turn or otherwise work
with the hand or hands.
         o.   Rotation: Frequently. Twist and turn the spine or a ball and
socket joint such as the shoulder or hip.
         p.   Talking: Constantly. Express or exchange ideas by means of the
spoken word to impart oral information to Village employees or officials or to
the public and convey detailed spoken instructions to other workers accurately,
loudly and quickly.
         q.   Hearing: Constantly. Perceive the nature of sounds by the ear.
         r.   Seeing: Constantly. Perceive the nature of sights by the eyes.
         s.   Reading: Read written reports, instructions and other relevant
writings.
         t.   Writing: Ability to accurately record inventory, information and
summaries of events.
         u.   Misc.: Such other physical and mental abilities that may be
required for the position.
   C.   The Village may request or desire a building inspection and grounds
maintenance employee to possess or maintain the following skills, licenses or
abilities:
      1.   A valid “Class B” or higher Illinois Commercial Driver’s License;
      2.   Any required Illinois pesticide spraying license necessary to
appropriately maintain the Village parks, grounds, or rights-of way;
      3.   Have a good working knowledge of carpentry, plumbing, and electrical
skills.
   D.   Residency: Shall reside within twenty-five (25) miles of the Village
corporate limits unless otherwise specified by an agreement with the Village
Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2023-35, 7-6-2023)
1-9J-5: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The duties and responsibilities of a building inspector and grounds maintenance
employee shall include, but are not limited to:
   A.   General Duties:
      1.   Serve under the direct supervision of the Director of Public Works
and designated Code Compliance Officer, and under the general supervision of
the mayor or mayor designee and Village Administrator;
      2.   Inspect new and existing construction for minimum conformance with
building construction codes and ordinances; responsible for ordering corrective
action and inspecting for compliance as required;
      3.   Enforce, by all appropriate means, all laws and ordinances of the
Village relating to the condition, construction, repair, alteration, addition
or maintenance of buildings and structures, including the Building and Housing
Codes (title 10, chapter 1 of this Code) and the Zoning Ordinance (title 11 of
this Code);
      4.   Review plans for proposed construction to determine compliance with
national, state, and Village construction codes, and the Village zoning
ordinance;
      5.   Review and respond to applications for building and occupancy
permits pursuant to title 10 of the Village Code;
      6.   Determine whether work requires permits and assure compliance with
required permitting processes and requirements;
      7.   Coordinate and conduct inspections of properties for which a
building or occupancy permit is requested;
      8.   Issue permits and collect fees for building construction,
demolition, and occupancy;
      9.   Be the primary person to locate, mark, and comply with J.U.L.I.E.
locates within the Village for Village infrastructure;
      10.   Be the designated Zoning Administrating Official if the position of
Zoning Administrating Official is not otherwise filled and in lieu of the Code
Compliance Officer;
      11.   Assist with the implementation, collection, and input of data for
the Village GIS system;
      12.   Assist with data collection of Village infrastructure to aid with
compliance with federal and state regulations and requirements and planning;
      13.   Coordinate and cooperate with the Randolph Township Fire District
Life Safety Code Compliance Officer pursuant to title 10 of this Code;
      14.   Assist with the maintenance of the grounds, rights-of-way, and
parks, including, but not limited to, the mowing, weed eating, trimming and
general landscape maintenance of the Village parks and rights-of-way, snow
removal of appropriate Village sidewalks and rights-of-way, and assist with
keeping Village sidewalks and parks free of inappropriate obstructions or
items;
      15.   Assist with the cleaning and maintenance of the Village Hall, park
restroom buildings and facilities, and other Village buildings;
      16.   Assist with the general maintenance and cleaning of Village
vehicles and equipment;
      17.   Perform and/or assist in basic carpentry, painting, plumbing,
electrical, concrete and other similar tasks relating to the repair and
maintenance of village owned buildings and facilities;
      18.   Maintain inventories and complete records of all work performed;
      19.   Maintain and provide accurate information and reports of inventory
to the budget officer and supervisors of the various village departments;
      20.   Assist with maintaining, moving or assembling furniture, and assist
with computer equipment and wiring;
      21.   Assist with performing preventative maintenance for plumbing,
heating, ventilation and air conditioning equipment including replacing belts
and changing filters;
      22.   Perform other such duties that are appropriate for the proper
conduct and operation of the affairs of the village; and
      23.   Perform such other duties as may be required by the mayor, mayor
designee, Village Administrator or department supervisor(s) consistent with the
laws and ordinances of the village. (Ord. 2023-35, 7-6-2023)
1-9J-6: INSPECTIONS; RIGHT OF ENTRY:
   A.   A building inspector and grounds maintenance employee, in the discharge
of his or her official duties and upon proper certification, shall have the
authority to enter any building, structure or premises at any reasonable hour.
   B.   A building inspector and grounds maintenance employee, when performing
and completing inspections in his or her formal capacity, shall not be
responsible for determining or advising persons of violations of all laws
relating to the condition, construction, repair, alteration, addition or
maintenance of buildings and structures. Failure of a building inspector to
strictly enforce any law relating to the condition, construction, repair,
alteration, addition or maintenance of buildings and structures shall not
relieve any person or corporation from adhering to those laws nor from being
responsible for any damage, repair or reconstruction that may be required as a
result of the failure to comply with any laws relating to the condition,
construction, repair, alteration, addition or maintenance of buildings and
structures. (Ord. 2023-35, 7-6-2023)
1-9J-7: STOP WORK ORDERS:
A building inspector and grounds maintenance employee shall have the power to
order work stopped on the construction, alteration, or repair of any building,
structure or premises when such work is being done in violation of any
ordinance. Work shall not be resumed after the issuance of such a stop order
except upon written permission of a building inspector and grounds maintenance
employee; provided, that if the stop order is issued verbally, it shall be
followed by a written stop order within one hour of the verbal order. Such
written stop order may be served by a building inspector and grounds
maintenance employee, any other authorized employee, or by any police officer
of the Village. (Ord. 2023-35, 7-6-2023)
CHAPTER 10
RESERVED
(Ord. 2015-46, 11-5-2015)
CHAPTER 11
BLOODBORNE PATHOGEN POLICY
SECTION:
1-11-1: Policy
1-11-2: Purpose
1-11-3: Definitions
1-11-4: Procedure
1-11-1: POLICY:
It shall be the policy of the village to comply with rules of the Illinois
department of labor relating to occupational exposure to blood or other
potentially infectious materials. (Ord. 2006-04, 3-20-2006)
1-11-2: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to inform village employees (employees) of
appropriate precautionary measures to be taken in circumstances where employees
may be exposed to infectious materials. It is the responsibility of each
employee to ensure not only self-compliance with this policy but to report any
violations of procedures to his/her immediate supervisor. (Ord. 2006-04, 3-20-
2006)
1-11-3: DEFINITIONS:
All definitions found in section 29 CFR 1910.1030(b) of the occupational safety
and health act, entitled "Bloodborne Pathogens", are hereinafter made part of
this chapter and shall apply when referred to herein. A hard copy may be found
in the police department supervisor's office. (Ord. 2006-04, 3-20-2006)
1-11-4: PROCEDURE:
   A.   Exposure Control Plan:
      1.   Statute Authority; Plan Developed: In accordance with the OSHA
bloodborne pathogens standard, 29 CFR 1910.1030, the following exposure control
plan has been developed:
         a.   The Illinois department of labor requires the village to perform
an exposure determination concerning which of its employees may incur
occupational exposure to blood and other potentially infectious materials. The
exposure determination is made without regard to the use of personal protective
equipment (i.e., employees are considered to be exposed even if they wear
personal protective equipment).
         b.   At the village, the following job classifications may have
occupational exposure to blood or other potentially infectious materials:
            (1)   Chief of police.
            (2)   Police sergeant.
            (3)   Police officers.
            (4)   Mayor.
            (5)   Village trustees.
            (6)   Office staff.
            (7)   Maintenance staff.
            (8)   Street employees.
            (9)   Labor employees.
      2.   Precautions And Compliance Methods:
         a.   Universal precautions, as defined under 29 CFR 1910.1030(b) shall
be taken by all employees of the village to prevent contact with blood or other
potentially infectious materials.
         b.   Village employees shall treat all blood and other potentially
infectious materials, as defined in the OSHA regulations as potentially
infectious, and follow all precautionary measures outlined in this section at
all times.
         c.   Whenever an employee's skin comes in contact with blood or other
potentially infectious materials, the employee shall immediately, or as soon as
possible, wash his/her hands and any other skin with soap and warm water, or
flush mucous membranes with water following the contact.
         d.   Whenever an employee of the village is exposed to any blood or
potentially infectious materials, the employee, as soon as possible, shall be
required to wash his/her hands in running warm water with a nonabrasive soap,
and then dry his/her hands with a clean cloth, paper towel or hand blower
device.
         e.   Employees exposed to blood or other potentially infectious
materials, which are in the field, shall use antiseptic hand cleaners when
handwashing facilities are not available.
When antiseptic hand cleaners are used, hands shall be washed with soap and
warm running water as soon as possible. Cleaner and towels/paper towels will be
provided by the village.
         f.   Employees wearing protective gloves or other personal equipment,
as soon as possible after removal of same, shall wash their hands immediately
or as soon as possible, using soap and warm water.
      3.   Personal Protective Equipment:
         a.   The village shall provide personal protective equipment to
village employees at no cost. This equipment shall not permit blood or other
potentially infectious materials to pass through or reach the employee's work
clothes, street clothes, undergarments, skin, eyes, mouth, or mucous membranes
under normal conditions when the personal protective equipment is worn.
         b.   Personal protective equipment shall be available at the following
locations:
            (1)   All marked and unmarked police vehicles.
            (2)   All workstations of employees who may be exposed to blood or
other potentially infectious materials.
            (3)   All supervisory offices.
